146212208.review:
The mental and emotional turmoil that this visual novel puts you through is insane.

I thought it would be like a typical type of Furry Visual Novel, especially regarding the content warning given at the beginning. My thought process being, "Oh, it's probably some dating sim with a few lewd instances here and there." But it is far more than that, the decisions I made in the game taking me through twists and turn I wouldn't have expect to see coming The good endings leave you with a warm heart and the bad, especially the unexpected, have seriously left me distraught. This is especially considering how much emotional investment I put in the story without even realizing it. 

The storylines were definitely entertaining and interesting to follow, especially after the first attempt getting into the story. Thanks to the guide I was also able to find many endings I wouldn't have been able to figure myself however, [spoiler] the ending with the Leopard Cat, in which you are able to have both Lin-Hu (Guardian Tiger) and Likulau (Clouded Leopard) posses you and eventually corner the Leopard Cat with the help of the other two and purify him and help him make up of his wrong-doings (including the killing of Liao's beloved friend and senpai) only to be able to confess his love after now devoting his life into making his wrong into rights [/spoiler] has truly put me into tears. 

This is without a doubt a beautiful creation and it makes me wish I could experience this story for the first time over and over again.

142988278.review: Soy un padre de 50 años, probablemente una de las personas más viejas que juegan este juego. Soy padre soltero de mi hijo, que ahora tiene 14 años. Mi hijo recientemente descargó nekojishi y en menos de una semana, ya había jugado durante más de 20 horas. Esto fue terrible para mí, ya que ya era bastante difícil para mí pasar tiempo con mi hijo, ya que él siempre sale con sus amigos o simplemente mira videos en Tiktok. Así que decidí pedir prestada una cuenta de Steam a un primo y comprar este juego para ver si podía jugar junto a él. Cargué el juego, hice el tutorial pero estaba atascado en lo que se suponía que debías hacer. Le pedí ayuda a mi hijo y organizó un juego para que yo me uniera. Me encantó porque era el mejor momento que había pasado con mi hijo desde que mi esposa había muerto. Desde entonces, este juego ha acercado a mi hijo y a mí nuevamente y ahora también pasamos tiempo juntos fuera de la casa. Este juego me recordó que hay diversión en todo, y nos ha traído tanto a mí como a mi hijo muchos recuerdos felices.

119783188.review:
[h1] It will surprise you! [/h1]
Alright, I'm not into novel games, but I've just sunk 10 hours into it non-stop. The story is an absolute treat that shocked me, intrigued me, gave me goose bumps, and pulled my heart strings more than once. It's in a league of its own. Please do not compare it to furry anime series out there, because you'll just end up thinking about [spoiler]Beastars[/spoiler], and we do not talk about [spoiler]Beastars[/spoiler]. Ever. Instead, i'd invite you to think back to wholesome furry comics of 2010s (Furpilled, Circles, Sequential Art, Better days, etc.). Different genre, same warm and fuzzy feeling of getting attached to your favorite characters. 

Folklore-wise, the game reminded me of the attempt Trese made to popularise Philipino folklore, but Nekojishi arguably did a way better job with Taiwanese myths and legends than that 'Edgefest' Netflix rolled out. 
The plot is anime-worthy and, if serialized, would do wonders to the industry full of the same formulaic titles that don't know where to stop with OP characters, power inflation, primitive romance lines, and drawn-out emotional arcs. 

But hey you're not here for an art critic's rant so go get yourself a furry husbando (or three!) already.  

11/10 wholesome furry boyfriends. Cannot recommend it more. 

P.S. special thanks to James Somerton for mentioning Nekojishi in his video on Gay Representation in Video games: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TQNKEkrPEfI

116240504.review:
This is an amazing story! Not a whole lot of differences with your choices, but it's done in a pretty good way. The endings are about the only thing that really has differences, unless your focusing on a single cat, instead of all of them at once. 

I definitely was teary eyed on a few parts and had my heart strings pulled quite a lot too. I really fell in love with Likulau though. He is hot af, but I'm really a big fan of his growth at the end of the good endings he's a part of. Leopard cat also had some good growth at the end of the perfect ending, but he's otherwise kinda annoying in my eyes. And last but not least, Guardian Tiger, he really does all the work at holding the story together and is the MC's guide through it all. He's the only one of the three that takes the MC's wants into account, and is always his stout advocate.

All in all, this story was as educational as it was entertaining. I'm not one to make any extra effort to get achievements for any game, but this is one of the few games where it's actually kind of fun to try to get them all. Granted, I don't have many at all (because I'm really bad at getting achievements lol), but I had fun getting the ones that I do have :) 

I recommend this game strongly for anyone who likes/loves furries, and anyone who likes a fairly decent story line and world lore.

96926353.review:
Having been familiarized with the genre of slice of life when it comes to anime I was happy to see that implemented into Nekojishi.  At initial glance I thought this visual novel would be fairly boring which is what stopped me from playing after getting 50 minutes into the story.  Giving this story another chance, however, I found out that this visual novel is more about living life instead of going on some journey selected by the user.  In a way, this visual novel is still a journey, but the journey is more about the sudden change in life the main character, Liao, goes through when he encounters three big cat spirits.

[b]Art:[/b]  The art is absolutely wonderful!  A small issue of mine is how most of the animation is used with the same poses of the cat spirits a majority of the time.  They do make it more worth it with all the shots seen throughout the story and thrown into the gallery as you progress but it would've been nice to see some more poses instead of the ones mainly used with small changes like having the eyes close.

[b]Music:[/b]  The music is also very good!  It's nothing extremely noteworthy but it's still of high quality.  None of the music in each of the scenes feel out of place and that greatly helps bring across the mood of the story as it progresses.

[b]Story (SPOILERS AHEAD):[/b]  The story itself is fantastic!  While I'm not all that big on the slice of life genre I like how this story utilizes it.  All the characters have their own quirks which makes them all very memorable through each scene you play through.  There's a fair amount of good and bad endings that are nice.  I do find the whole [spoiler]doing romantic stuff to be able to possess your body stuff[/spoiler] to be odd, though I'm a bit used to it being here.  I, however, have a bit of an issue when it comes to the true ending of this game.  This ending, while it has the most positives, feels slightly bittersweet to me.  In this ending, [spoiler]Leopard Cat reveals that he has wanted to eat your soul the entire time you've been with him, simply because he thinks it will be delicious.  Liao, possessed by Guardian Tiger, is romantic to Leopard Cat as a means to stop him.  This action gives Leopard Cat more power as to become a better spirit.[/spoiler]  This ending bothers me since this character is definitely my favorite of the three, and the fact that [spoiler]his eyes aren't opened without being put in a romantic place[/spoiler] kinda bothers me.  Maybe I'll get more used to it over time or my feelings will change as I play through the epilogue DLC but I'd rather this ending be adjusted completely rather than having it be left as is.  Regardless, I still think this whole story works great within the slice of life genre.

[b]Overall:[/b]  While I'm not huge on the true ending, I overall find this to be a well-crafted visual novel.  There are some other things I didn't point out like how there are several spelling and grammar errors throughout, but that's only because of how it was initially in a different language and I've seen this happen plenty of times to not mind.

87877862.review:
This VN is something you could finish in a few hours, but with high replay value due to its many varying endings and hidden achievements. If you're into completionism, it's fun to experiment unlocking all those tricky hidden things. 

Speaking of CGs, there aren't many if you don't get any of the expansions, but those which there are are extremely beautiful and well done--you could stare into the different details forever, nothing is spared on the backgrounds and intricate clothing. I do wish that there was more full body sprites instead of the same few being flipped around for almost the entire game, but we do get cute reaction headshots next to their dialogue. 

However, while Nekojishi is light on content, that does not mean it's a relaxing cuddly affair. After the first in game week, this game gets heart wrenching and really makes that choice of who to go with way more complicated than expected. Every character is decently well written, with good comedic timing and well placed foreshadowing, and the immature sexual humour in the first half really undermines how emotionally fraught this game can be. 

I would recommend this game to people who like furry art and who want a VN with an intriguing plot, rather than an Otome that mostly focuses on racking up love points and earning kawaii girl pictures.

86443206.review:
Nekojishi....Where do I start with this game? 

[b]Lets start with the pros:[/b]

Graphics-wise, it's really well done. The characters are very detailed and cute, even though I'm not a furry or gay, I still loved the artstyle of this game. (If you're wondering, I like Shu Chi Senpai most lol) It adds a more casual feel when playing the game.

Secondly, the interface and animations. It is well programmed and the buttons do what they are supposed to do, the little animations and sound effects that made the characters move when they are expressing emotion was spot on, adding to the cuteness of the game. It also helped the characters express their emotions better, even if they are just still images on the screen.

Thirdly, the story line. It is very well written, every ending brings an lasting impression. The way the story leads up to the ending is mostly very upbeat and entertaining and it really allowed the players to learn more about each character in the story, watching them grow and develope their own stories. I found in the process in playing this game, the life of the player character is actually quite normal (Well if you ignore that he has the power to see Guardian Cats, gods and spirits) He has his own university life, does whatever a normal person does. The way this normal life leads to the endings is very thrilling.

Now, there are the endings themselves, I did not expect this game to give me such a lasting emotional impression. Every different ending of the story gave me a new insight and feel for the characters. What I didn't expect most is that the overwhelming amount of guilt and somberness the game has managed to express, now I know there are happy endings to the story, but some choices made were devastating for some of the characters in the game, especially to Lilaku and Shu Chi Senpai. The game makes you feel the guilt no matter what, not just when you make the choice, but at the endings as well. Now that's good writing!

[b]Now, for the cons:[/b]

I don't think I have much to say here, the game was very well made. From the graphics to the story, amazing. However, If I were to critisise one point of this game, I think the process of getting the different endings are too complicated, there are a lot of choices. You wouldn't know what choice you made wrong until it is too late. But that's just my opinion.

Hope you found my review helpful, leave a comment or a like :) It'll be much appreciated.

79589640.review:
I originally downloaded Nekojishi as a joke, thinking it was just another furry yaoi game, and, while it left me somewhat dissatisfied in that aspect (not completely, if you were worried of that), my experience playing this game may have been the most important factor in my development as a person.

In no uncertain terms or any exaggeration, this game changed my life. Nekojishi is a game makes you think a lot, forcing the player to re-evaluate their decisions through meaningful consequences. Selfless options can come to a loss in this game, as is true to real life. This game, in part, helped me be more outgoing in real life, showing me that you don't have to please everyone, and that the best way to have a positive impact on a lot of people's lives is to get out there and be yourself. While "being yourself" is a common cliché, this game subtly carries that message in a deep and personal way. 

If you are looking for a quick and simple game with a shallow story, you'll be forced to look further. Nekojishi's emotionally complex and varied endings provide a deep connection to the world and story, displaying depth and character comparable to some of the greatest pieces of literature ever written. The first time I did a full playthrough of this game, the ending I was left with was heart-wrenchingly sad. It, along with a few other things, served as the catalyst for an emotional and philosophical following few nights, and I believe I came out a better man from it. This game has a few tragic endings, along with some more cheery ones to balance it, but all of them are beautifully constructed to leave lasting memories.

This game is so much more than some trashy furry yaoi game. It is accurate to real life in character, despite the mythical parts, and will bring out emotions you might not have ever experienced otherwise. 

10/10. A life changing experience.

76463229.review:
Well. That was intense, heh. 

At this point I did my first playthrough and I have to say, even though Furry is not exactly a fetish of mine - but still appealing, I fell in love with this virtual novel as soon as I saw the intro cinematic before the main menu even popped up.

First I have to say that the english translation, as far as I can compare it to other VN's that originate from the east (And the fact that I'm no native english speaker as well, since I'm from Germany), is superb with only a hand full of errors that were barely noticeable. The characters are very adorable and likeable, even though a certain character obviously (and seemingly) having a crush on you right off the bat is a red flag for me, if you catch my drift. 

You're being put into an impossible situation and I for myself constantly wondered how to go about it. The story is well written and the glossary is very helpful as well, teaching me some foreign culture I never even thought about. I've read many novels of not so professional writers (Chapters App), so I've experienced some pretty stereotypical formats. Just saying this because I'm not reading paperback - writers can't and shouldn't be compared in general. What I want to say is, that for me the plot was very refreshing and interesting and I only stopped because I had to pee or eat (And even then I've still kept reading while eating, heh.).

For something free of charge, this has been definitely worth my time and I'm going to explore the other routes as well. However, while I like to focus on the good things, I must say that even though it kept me going for like 4-5 hours for one playthrough on average speed, it's pretty short.

Let me rephrase; I want more. I feel like the story has a lot of potential if being worked on and I understand that it's not as easy to create a visual novel. I'd try it myself, but I'm not good at programming, scripting or whatever needs to be done and I'm no visual artist either. I hope in the future there will be more of it, or more stuff like this. 

Another thing that irked me a little was that I didn't get to know the side characters better and that there was really only one real crisis I had to go through, even if the situation in itself is a crisis.

In conclusion all I can say that this is a wonderful peace, furry or not. Very adorable, lightheaded and enjoyable. Please consider giving it a shot, you can't go wrong with this one.

#TeamLeopard

73348440.review:
In Nekojishi, you play as a broke college student that must balance school life, religion, and being a closet gay furry while three sexy tiger dudes tell you to stop procrastinating and help them out with something. On the surface level, it's a furry dating simulator, but beneath that layer is a clear celebration of Taiwanese culture, both Indigenous Austronesian and Han Chinese.

The story is interesting, well written for the most part, very comedic, and it touches on some themes and topics not often discussed in most other media. Visuals are pretty good, a lot of the background locations are actual places around Taiwan (you could use this game as a travel guide). Character designs are amazing, very appealing if you happen to be a gay furry, but also very relevant to what the characters represent. Sound design is okay, main theme is catchy, other songs in the game are also pretty good, but there's also a bunch of generic sounding VN music. Gameplay, well, it's a Visual Novel.

My only real gripe with the game is that any ending other than the perfect one is unsatisfying, and with a DLC and upcoming sequel, it makes you wonder why the other endings were included in the first place. If Nekojishi was a linear story or if it had handled branching paths in a better way, then it probably would have been perfect. Regardless, I still heavily recommend the game; It's cute, fun, you can learn a bit about other cultures, and it's free.

Also Likulau is best boy.

67106192.review:
On the face of it, this seems like a really good game, and it is for a while. It begins to fall apart when the tiger gets angry and Liao just accepts it. It begins to fall apart when you try to go on a date and a car hits you. It begins to fall apart when Shu Chi directly asks you a question that you have an answer to and it just... doesn't give you the options.

What I'm saying is that this game has a penchant for contrived conflict that gets legitimately frustrating after a while. Some of the endings seem to be terrible just for the sake of being terrible, like "hey you wanted to go on a DATE? in a BIG GAY GAME? fuck YOU!" It gets old very, very quickly when the main character behaves almost exactly the way I wouldn't for the purpose of advancing the story. In fact, if you look at the list of possible endings, it goes something like "bad bad good very sad sad sad good tragic tragic perfect," which is just plain not fun in my opinion. 

I wrote notes as I was playing through this, and one of the things I wrote is "game will you get it through your thick skull that i want to see liao and shu chi have a happy and fulfilling life together." Other lines include "i really don't like this false dilemma; it's not a dilemma if i've decided already," and "this game has some real terrible endings; i've had two of them so far and neither was even remotely satisfying for any of the three characters."

If you want a sort of similar game that actually gets to the romance instead of dangling it in your face like a bunch of carrots (and then crashing a car into you), try Tennis Ace. It's just one guy making this story for three years, and even though it's incomplete, it's actually amazing, story-wise. It uses the visual novel format to its fullest extent and tells three compelling, not to mention lengthy, stories that don't end with a cheap tug at the heartstrings. I highly recommend it.

Each route/ending has their own appeal, they're full of emotion, plot twists, and some regrets.
The soundtrack is another strong point of the game, the tracks set the tone for what's happening. I think the upbeat ones are nice to listen to outside of the game, while the melancholic tracks are full of emotion. They remind me of better days, and when I first came across this game.

The DLC is very short and I still recommend it but it's quite linear so it doesn't have any branching paths. It's also more lighthearted than some of the base game.

All the cats are good in their ways. (And I'm gay for all of them)
8/10
Waiting for the sequel.

63915905.review:
When I first got the game, I was expecting some awkward gay furry dating sim I could laugh at, given the sexual content/nudity tags. In a severe turn of events, however, this turned out to be one of the best stories I've ever had the pleasure of playing through. I've laughed as much as I have teared up playing this game, and connected with the characters more then I ever thought I could. Nekojishi is a tragic story as much as it is a fun one.This was supposed to be a joke game for me, but ended up being a game I'll recommend with full serious intent. If you're not going to read the rest of this review, let me say: Don't let the whole "gay furry" thing drive you away, this game much more then that.

[h1]Story[/h1]
Nekojishi, follows the story of Liao, a college student who just wants to make it through his ordinary life. This all changes when his third eye is opened and he can now see spirits and gods. With his third eye opened, Liao is dragged into a position where he must decide the future of three beast men.
This game starts off light hearted, but gets deep and serious fast. Your choices visually affect all the characters, and some choice can be the difference between life and death. The choices you'll need to make will feel hard, and most choices involve trading off something or come with consequences.
This game has a very deep narrative involving Taiwanese folklore. To help you with fully understanding everything Taiwanese, the game actually has a pretty in depth Glossary. An info icon will pop up every time you discover a new word you may not know, and clicking it will give you detailed information. I've learned a lot from this game, and have actually been inspired to learn Chinese after playing.

[h1]Characters/The Whole "Same-sex romance" Thing[/h1]
So here's a pretty nice starter. I walked into this game still pretty confident I was straight. I still enjoyed this game even though I walked in having no interest in same-sex romances. However, this game did spark a pretty big interest in such. This being the first same-sex romance game I've played, I don't think I've ever actually looked into whether I'm actually straight or not. Oh well, guess I'm Bisexual now or something. Thanks Likulau for making me gay or something like that. Anyways, back to a more serious tone...
The characters are VERY easy to connect to. Each have distinct personalities and ways of doing things. Getting connected to a character only to end up hurting them with a choice you needed to make is the hardest part of the game, but sometimes it needs to be done. These characters will be remembered for years to come.
Also, did I mention Likulau is the best kitty? Oh uhhhh...ahem, right, I'm still not done with this review.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
The art in this game is amazing, and beat out a fair amount of even the paid visual novels out there. Everything is so detailed, the sprites even adjust to the lighting as you travel! There are a good deal of CGs in the game, and all look fantastic.
The UI looks fine, and is non-invasive.

[h1]Sound[/h1]
The game has a pretty good sound track. Quite a few of the songs are variants of the game's main theme, but still all sound heavily unique. The songs don't burn out after countless hours of hearing them, which is great!

[h1]Issues[/h1]
This game isn't perfect, but it's MOSTLY perfect. I had a hard time finding things to write here, but some issues include...
-There are some spelling errors and typos in the english version. Given they are few and far in between, it's still worth mentioning.
-DLC issues when playing in English, specifically the voice over. The game will read a few text boxes ahead at times, and moving on to the next text box before the voice over is done will result in silence until you catch up to the voice over.

In the end, I'd say just give the game a shot, regardless of your sexuality or interest in beast men/furries. If the three kitties don't hook you on the game, the powerful story and Taiwanese lore will.  Also, a tip on the DLC, the "Sunny Day" extra pack adds CGs to the main story as well, so I'd recommend getting it before you're finished with the main story.

62770787.review:
Okay, so I found myself coming back to this after having played it a while back. I like visual novels and this was free and had some gorgeous looking art, so I was down to give it a try even though it clearly is meant to appeal to furries. I have seen plenty of furry stuff in my time, being a denizen of the internet, so it didn't feel weird to me and I could just think of them as magical spirits, like the game implies. If you're someone who also isn't a furry but likes visual novels, I would suggest giving this a try anyway, unless you're uninterested in reading a story about a boy who is sexually attracted to cat spirits, which, I can't really blame you. From here on I'm going to continue on about why I like this story.

As a story, I found this fascinating. Not only does it explore a culture I knew next to nothing about (I have learned a lot!), but as I said before the artist involved does better art than some on the $60 visual novels I see out there. There is a lot of content, it's not a short little thing, and while it does spend time doing cutesy anime tropes like hot springs and uwu I like them but I shouldn't, the core of the story is actually a very difficult decision the main character has to make about his life. At the start it is played up for laughs a bit, but as time goes on, each spirit becomes more desperate for the protagonist's help. Each one NEEDS the protagonist for one reason or another, and the writing exploring this is very grounded and serious. I found myself truly struggling with what i would do. Each one is trying their hardest and saying no to any of them is devastating (I don't want to spoil the specifics of their situations, learning the depth of their problems is part of the joy of reading). 

There are plenty of dating sims games I've played that have been air-headed fan service with characters whose existence serves no purpose other than to fantasize having them as your waifu. I expected this to be the same but was instead drawn into the writing completely. Don't get me wrong, there is a lot of fan service. This may be a hard game to play if you have no attraction to men. Still, even that aspect is analyzed by the story. The protagonist is even chastized for objectifying them at one point, instead of focusing on his decision! The fact that they are spirits is also interestingly explored by myth and writing as well. I really do love what they do with the world building they establish.

I'm starting to ramble, but I hope my review gets someone who might ot have tried to to give it a chance. It is well put together and written with weight and history. I'm planning to get the rest of the routes now and I'm looking forward to it.

For a free game this is really nice. I'd say it's good enough that it doesn't hurt to play. If you're a furry, gay or any demographic in which this type of game would appeal, I'd say you'd like it fine. If you're like me and just like animals in a mainstream way, you'll find some flaws. Quite plainly, it's a game meant to appeal to furries mainly and has a bit too much of anime romance cliches for my likely. Still, I'd be lying if I said I didn't like it to some extent. 

The biggest issue is that it seems very difficult to get different endings. I've tried to play this game multiple times on speed just to see what endings I could get. Getting with Tiger is the easiest, but otherwise I always ended up with no one or dying. Even when I supported one of the other characters 100% I didn't end up getting with them. If Tiger is not your favorite out of the cats, it's likely you'll get a somewhat disappointing ending your first time and if you weren't totally invested in the first place, it'll be doubly disappointing. 

The pacing is very slow and there are only about 8-12 choices in a 5ish hour game. Personally I like Telltale's format a lot more, but this is fairly pleasant for what it is.

51112734.review:
I enjoy Visual Novel games with a sincere and relatable character, variety of choices/decisions and awesome art. Nekojishi just so happens to satisfy these attributes, especially for its visuals.  For a small Developer team, Team Nekojishi did a stunning job at the graphics and effects, and that is already seen with the Opening. Each and every character has details that match the etiquette of the culture that this story takes place in (Taiwan), and I’m a huge fan of oriental themes and environments. There’s a Gallery in the Menu options, too, which captures the most stunning pictures from the stories that you unlocked. It’s a must-see when you attained all the endings!   

The story was nothing special, but was easy to understand/follow. You play as a character named Liao, who goes through the everyday life and struggles as a college student - with the addition of having 3 Guardian Tiger companions by his side. Here is where you choose who you can interact and eventually be with in the end (or even none), amidst the drama and decisions we make. I found Leopard Senpai’s endings to be the most melancholic and character progressive, but to each their own. Other players would argue differently for who they like.  [spoiler]I love Guardian Tiger.[/spoiler]  

Music and audio were also decent and soothing. They had all the ingredients to any typical VN, where they merge with the environment, or special sounds being triggered based on your decisions in-game. The Opening song also was nice, albeit not too memorable.   

 A Limited edition pack also exists … which, I won’t be downloading. It’s limited for a reason, after all! Overall, Nekojishi was a blast. I have completed all the endings, and though it may not be a game I’d play again, after the hype has died, it is definitely worth a try!

50796172.review:
Given how good the game is, I honestly was shocked it was free. I've paid for things that weren't nearly as good. 

There are some grammar mistakes and a few typos, and if I had to give a major criticism to the story it's that it starts really slow. Painfully slow. Even fastforwarding through the beginning section takes a good while on replays; so make sure you create a save at that first choice to save on time. But after you're over the intro, where Liao is pretty repetitive, it really starts to hit it's stride. 

There's a lot of really interesting things to the plot that I didn't really expect from the game. I really like the perfect ending, I feel it's a good balance of all the things the game wants to do and it accomplishes it pretty well. There's quite a few bitter sweet endings, and the bad endings are impactful in a good way. Nothing is too far out there that it's rough to sit through, or that ruins the whole game or characters on subsequent playthroughs. Even though it could have easily gone that way (as some other VN have done for me).

The Limited Edition patch is great, though I did actually find the Standard version of the perfect ending to be better in terms of plot. I'm not sure why they cut some of the parts out for the LE (explicit) version. I feel like some of the heartfelt dialog could've been adapted to the LE version just fine.

Great art, the music never got on my nerves, the zooms and movements of certain characters conveyed humor and drama really well given how limited the format can be. 

I do kind of wish there was a bit more side content though. Akin to Coming Out on Top having side dates, if Liao could've had a dream about Ragoo for example... or other side characters. CooT actually has a dream for certain characters who you can't romance come to think of it... 

I'd say it'd be nice if we could view the character portraits [ingame art]. Given there's a variety of them per character.

First thing I saw was the beautiful anime-like intro with beautiful voice singing the theme song and I already knew I'd love this game. Both the visuals and story of this masterpiece are simply amazing, and even though the furry concept of the characters might not be appealing to some audience, the story will surely keep them playing. All the folklore references are a big plus, because you both learn about the culture, and experience it yourself by going through all the dialogues with well-written characters. Game has multiple endings, and despise the fact that I haven't gotten them all, those I got really played on my emotions, and I believe other ones will too. Sadly, there is no perfect game. The biggest flaws of this one I've noticed so far, are bugged achievements, mismatched character icons with dialogues and the voice-acting in the DLC, which most of times lacks emotions and completely doesn't match the characters. Overall, Nekojishi is a wonderfully designed game. Great characters, beautiful visuals, interesting story, and if I had to rate it on a scale of 1-10, I'd give it a solid 10.

50110386.review:
Okay, here goes.

There are a lot of joke reviews about this game, but I'm personally very fond of it. I admire it, and I think it's brave. I understand why the creator would want it to exist on a number of levels.

I mean, yes, it's a heartwarming story that draws on cultural values, beliefs, and tenets so that's obvious, but more than that it's a thing of comfort for anyone who feels outside of the norm. As an actually autistic (diagnosed) person who has bodily dysphoria issues thanks to abuse (too many welts and dents to count), who enjoys escaping into stories of non-humans as a coping mechanism when things get too hard? Stuff like Nekojishi actually helps me. I know that's not something that many neurotypicals will be able to understand, but that's really how I feel.

If I had the guts, I'd love to do something like this but about my own culture. I'd love to tell a tale about the Wolves of Ossory (werewolves) and the Dreigiau (dragon spirits, upon which Western dragons were loosely based, though these ones aren't evil or greedy).

I've been thinking about how I'd review this for a while because despite obviously being a gay doujin visual novel, it's... wholesome, it's got great characters, and it has a surprising amount of depth. I really enjoyed this. And on the darker days when I'm reading about stuff like the Judge Rotenberg Centre and forced autism "cures" which are effectively just torture, I'll turn to something comforting like Nekojishi to escape it all.

I like fictional creatures, they can be whatever I want them to be and they're generally better than real people are, even at their worst moments. Even at their worst, there's a kindness to them that I find all too rare. Perhaps that's just something that I'm projecting, but it's something I could only project onto non-human characters as I've experienced so much abuse at the hands of neurotypicals.

I liked this story, I liked how all issues are overcome with such kindness in the true ending. I appreciate that you shared this with all of us without asking for anything in return. I have since bought the DLC, the soundtrack, and some merch as I wanted to show my support but I really do appreciate the sentiment of offering it for free.

This is a really vulnerable position so I'm going to disable comments on this review because people can be bloody mean-spirited, but I just wanted to thank you for this and say how much I've enjoyed it and why.

I may eventually regret posting this but there you go.

49323314.review:
I'm obviously a biased reviewer for this game, cause as you can see, I'm a tiger. The first day I saw this, I honestly thought it was gonna be low quality in many of it's features. But I honestly couldn't have been further from the truth. Nekojishi is a wonderful game that had my attention to the end. I mean just seeing how many hours I put into this game should make things clear of my appreciation for it. The story and plot don't come off as a dating sim, at least most of the time. It instead reads like a fantasy novel, which is my favorite kind of stories. In complete honesty, I cried at the first ending I made it to. It's so heartfelt and attaches you to each character like they really are developed from a real person. 
    The soundtrack helps with that emotional feel, making sure to let the mood of the setting become unmistakable and quite the tearjerker on many parts. The artwork and expressions were very well done, and the DLC did a wonderful job adding more to the art. The DLC (A Sunny Day) epilogue itself was just as nice as the main story despite it being much shorter. 

    Now despite all these wonderful pros, there were a couple flaws to the game in my opinion. The first one would have to be the language translation. I don't know how well it was in Chinese and the other languages, because unfortunately I don't know that many languages. But as for the English version, it's got many spelling errors, punctuation problems, and other grammar issues. It sometimes killed the mood for me, not to say it was entirely bad because it made me laugh a few times. I also noticed that the form of English that was translated was for UK. I laughed real hard at the times the characters used the words "bloody" (as in bloody hell), "metro" (for subway/train station), among a few other words. That's not necessarily a bad thing either, because it's not like there's anything wrong with UK English vs US, just wanted to point that part out. However, the grammar is a problem and probably should have been checked over when originally written. 
      Another problem was the steam achievements. I completely understand why they were all secret. It's a story rich game, it would be a lot less fun if you already knew how to get the achievements because it would just spoil a ton of the story. But my real issue is the actual achievements themselves. A good majority of them are near impossible to find because the likelihood you'd just stumble across a certain pattern of choices that would lead you to the achievement. And because the achievements are hidden, there would be no way to even guess how to get them. I played over 50 hours to get all the endings and artwork without using a guide. And once I saw what the other achievements were, it kinda made me feel a bit bad having to try getting them. Like having one character not have any affection for you, or having a brutal death. It's just better not to have those kind of achievements at all. Though the rest of them were pretty good.
This last complaint isn't much of a problem. It's about the audience. Not many people would probably wanna play as a homosexual boy with other male characters. 
**SPOILER ALERT** 
The fact that the characters didn't have a fixed gender and only looked as the human viewer percieved, it seemed weird to me that there wasn't an option to have the characters female.
**END OF SPOILER** 
I mean I understand why there wouldn't be an option to make the characters female, but I just thought I'd mention it, cause I thought it would be interesting and give a bigger audience. But as I said, it's not much of a problem, just a sort of side thought.

The other extra content was alright. The Nekojishi Voice, where they had voice actors for each of the character besides the one you viewed the story as. It wasn't bad, and I don't know how well the acting was because it wasn't in my language. But personally as an American, I'd was better without the Voice. I instead read it on my own and even voiced over as the characters myself, along with a few friends. We had much more fun doing that, but I still thought the actual voice actors did a fair job. I didn't buy the soundtrack, but I sometimes get tempted to because the music was so great for me. One of my friends have it and he loves listening to it all the time.

Overall, I personally believe this game was amazing. It had a wonderful story, great soundtrack, lively characters, and the game is FREE. Like even if you're skeptical, you're not going to be wasting a single cent. There's nothing stopping you from getting it even if you're poor as heck. The main game is free, which makes it totally okay for the DLC stuff to cost money. Nekojishi has been one of my favorite story rich games and I one day plan on playing it again.

45857703.review:
Okay now, I typically don't like these types of games anyway, so please forgive me. I downloaded this because the art seemed fantastic and the plot was something I hadn't really heard before. 
I'm so sorry but even if this were a book the only reasonable thing to do with it is to use it as tinder.
At least it was free. I acknowledge that even if I personally did not like this game, it still must've taken a heap of time and work to do, and I respect that - I respect every single game maker and artist, whether it's music or drawing or cooking. This was just... A dish I did not like in a restaurant I should've known not to enter.
If you still wanna read my rant of "criticism":
The game itself was a disappointment. It shouldn't be called a game because there is nothing to play. There's no interaction whatsoever. You just click until your hand dislocates from the shoulder, and read until your eyes bleed. Also, who wrote this? A 13-year old girl probably, and I know that's a harsh thing to say, but I wrote stuff like this when I was 13. The flavor of it is just naive and worn out. It's new and fresh only to someone who themselves is new and fresh to anything like this. There is nothing original to the whole package, except for the art. The characters are carbon copies of everything that's a standard mold in anime, manga, manwha and the like.  Spoiler alert: there's a hunky kind manly dude, an athletic, quiet, mystic foreigner, and a talkative, optimistical, clinky uke type with a leaner body. All the 3 basic flavors of asian comic culture, no side dishes, no gimmicks, just... Nothing new under the sun. The main character is an annoying little brat who seems to go "ahh~~ I shouldn't~~ but I kind of will~~ But I should'n~~" "kyaa you scared me~~" "you can't just-- !!! but I will do nothing about it if you do--!!!" about just ANYTHING. Everything is a surprise to him and everything seems like the biggest decicion and... There's just not an ounce of originality to this.
Wasted my time, but good luck to anyone who loves stories like this, with characters like this. You've hit a gold mine.

45846006.review:
I'm happy to admit that this game is great. Starting from a really nice intro, awesome music theme and on a really good drawings ending. I came here looking for a visual novel after trying out "The Poisonous Fountain" (Which I recommend as well) and I immediately got a mouthdrop. 
The game has everything you could expect from a visual novel and much more. The characters are colourful, vibrant and differ from each other like fire and ice. And yet each of them is lovable and care about the main character in their own ways. I almost got into tears a few times when I had to say "goodbye" to some of them. There are a few unexpected plot twists really well woven into the main plot that cause emotions from happiness and serenity to anger and hate. And speaking of emotions, since the game is available on Steam, it focuses on romantic relationships, feelings and the way of expressing them rather than sexual content. The most lewd moments in the story include bathing together and french kissing so morality defenders should be satisfied. Out of journalistic duty I need to mention that there is a patch in the net that enriches the version with bed scenes, but you need to be adult (and gay or at least like such stuff since all avalable characters to interact with are furry males) to run it. 

Pros:
- grat story
- wonderful music
- unexpected twists
- really good art / graphics
- a glossary explaining some of south-asian culture and beliefs in an interesting and educatiing way

Cons:
- some endings are really difficult to find
- no female characters ( not visible at least, may be a problem to some but not me heh, he)

Give it a try. Even if you're not into M/M relationships you will still find interesting and rewarding content. You may even learn something about relationships and how to deal with them. And if you really can't stand seeing two males in a romance, please take your cold, dead heart elsewhere as quoiting the character in another game "you are a sad person and I have no desire to talk to you any longer".

45442773.review:
I've first learned of Nekojishi about 6 months ago. I was scrolling through Twitter when I saw someone talking about it. I watched what I believe to be one of the first trailers and got pretty excited because, well, let's be honest: it's already hard to find furry visual novels, let alone ones that are targeted to the male gay audience. Unfortunately, I was very busy with work, so I couldn't play it as soon as I wanted to. 

Fast forward to today, with much more free time in my hands, I decide to give Nekojishi a try, since I postponed it for so long. I downloaded it from the official web site and got instantly hooked. I could not stop playing it! The opening, the way the characters are presented, their interactions, their dynamic together, the soundtrack, the CGs, the funny moments... just... wow. 

One day later, I bought everything that's available on Steam. If you can afford to, I highly recommend buying at least the Chinese voice pack, as it greatly enhances the experience. Even though I don't speak Chinese, I believe the voice actors did a really good job in portraying the characters emotions. By the time the story got to its climax, I could feel like I was there with the characters. I wanted to hug them and tell them that everything was going to be okay. I won't spoil anything, but if you have a fragile heart like me, be prepared for a lot of twists. After finishing my first playthrough and getting one of Likulau's endings, I was devasted for the rest of day, not by the ending per se, as it was quite happy, but by all the events that led to it. It was surely a rollar coaster of emotions. 😩

To sum up, this game got a special place in my heart. I highly recommend it to anyone looking for a good story. I wanted to thank the dev team for the amazing work, so I've decided to leave a review. Thank you very much! I'll definitely continue to support you guys in the future. 😊

(i'll probably add way more once i get farther) I enjoy visual novels, so I thought I would enjoy this one, too. The moment I opened the game, I knew I would have a blast. The intro that plays when you open the game is stunningly amazing, I rewatch it every now and then just to see the beautiful effort that was put into it. Having the Glossary feature is actually extremely helpful, I actually learned something from it! The gameplay is pretty simple; learning that all your life, you were being watched by a guardian tiger; a leopard cat has started possessing your Senpai, and a clouded leopard had enchanced your vision, allowing you to see spirits. It's pretty much hanging out with the spirits, and trying to go through with college. Alongside that, exciting adventures await you, while you have to make difficult choices to make all your spirit friends happy. Complete masterpiece, I wouldn't change a thing, heheheh, even for Senpai. 10/10.

44415000.review: A gay furry visual novel/dating sim with themes of being in the closet, family vs self, the needs of others versus your own desires, Taiwanese mythology, and an excelent, touching story. While it certainly isn't for everyone, given that there are a few, er, suggestive moments, I did find it quite enjoyable. The artwork and music in this game is absolutely beautiful, and you can tell how much effort everyone working on this game put into it. There are 12 different possible endings, giving the game lots of replay value, but getting each ending is kind of necessary to understand the entire story. Without going into spoiler territory, each ending has its own sort of feel to it- some happy, some sad, and some tragic. Each ending was a tearjerker for me, so if you're into games that really make you feel, then this is definatley for you.

To start off, furries. It's the first thing that caught my eye of this game, and I'm sure that's the reason why it caught other people's eyes as well. I find furries very cute and adorable, but you know, sometimes fans of furries take it a little bit too far.
If you are okay with furries and enjoy general visual novel and dating sims that take a slow pace, then this game is great for you. Unlike me, I was playing this game with friends who weren't so fond of furries, and they kind of ruined my interest in the game. We were browsing through games and I saw this, all I could think in my head was: "A FURRY DATING SIM????? GET THIS RIGHT NOW", and so I got it, because why not.
I feel like I just couldn't enjoy this game as much as I would of liked to because of the 'furries', or the tigers, leopards, etc, as they are stated in the game. Being called senpai and calling others senpai was kind of just awkward, and to me this game seemed a bit too pushed to seem like a normal dating sim. The game didn't even seem realistic in itself in the first place anyway. Literally the first option you have in the game is which of the three mains do you want to sleep with; like seriously, come on...
I can't really decide whether to recommend it or not, but, all I can say is that the game was pretty boring to play. There weren't many choices and the dialouge just seemed to go by so slow.

43616622.review:
I like to play more of the "eccentric" or niche games out there on steam, especially free ones.
This one caught my attention with the animated music video, which isn't something I see often on here.  I downloaded the game, expecting it to be mostly cutesy furry drama with a gay kid.  And in some ways, that's what it was.

However, the game focused on a surprising amount of Taiwanese lore, most of which is accurate, and directed its plot, characters (motives, personalities, conflicts), and challenges with the lore in mind.  I thought it did an excellent job forming a world background, making the game feel bigger than what it was, and keeping the plot true to the lore.  The characters had excellent designs and although their personalities weren't entirely unique, the plots in which they followed become heaily intertwined.  
Overall, I'd give this game an 8.5/10 for a visual novel.  A lot of work went into making this and it certainly pays off.

43359847.review:
Truth be told, I got this game because I thought it'd be a cutesy dating sim with three cute kitties. But the game is so much more than that; it's got heart, with a story that's certainly going to make you feel for its characters regardless of the path you choose. The soundtrack also helps; man, I love the music in this visual novel.

I will say that the romance aspect of the story isn't quite what I thought it would be. The game's got its cute moments, but the majority of it revolves around the lore of the game. However, I'd argue that the emphasis on folklore has an impact on the relationships you form with each of the love interests.

The plot is rather complicated, so I recommand familiarising yourself with the terminology you encounter on your journey. The game has a handy Glossary menu so you can refer to it whenver you need to refresh yourself on anything. I think the game's most enjoyable if you're expecting a good story to be told. There's a lot to wrap your head around (especially if, like me, you're walking into it having no knowledge of the folklore) but it makes for a better experience.

So all in all, I'd definitely recommend this. Come for the cute kitty guys, stay for the emotional rollercoaster that is the plot (and also for the cute kitty guys XD)

43289417.review:
i I'm sure you're charmed by the quirky reviews this game has, because I was too. charmed enough, even, to play away nine hours of my life on a game that i really cannot stand. and i actually had typed out a very lengthy review about every little thing that irked me, and before i could finish my soul was sapped from my body and I can barely handle typing this second draft out. 

This game is a waste of time if: 
- you're looking for a VN with a genuinely engaging plotline that actually captures your attention and imagination
- you want good character development from the love interests who [i]actually[/i] develop different morals, thoughts, feelings, etc
- you expect the rising action, climax, and falling action of the story to be well thought out and thought provoking, emotional, theatrical, or intense
- you expect to become genuinely attached to any of the love interests and actually come to love the way they are protrayed
- you're looking to experience a really sweet and genuine romance that makes a lasting impression on you
- you expected the twists and turns of the plot to be at the very least thoughtfully planned, and even if its not completely unpredictable it is still enjoyable to witness

if you wanted any of those things, or hold VN's to a high standard, I can honestly say this game probably isnt for you. This game has none of that. Does it have cute moments? Sure. Are the character designs nice? Yes. Was there actual knowledgable information in the game? Yes, but this game sucked the will to live right out of me and I didn't have the motivation to read the folklore sprinkled into the game. I expect a lot out of games like these, because if I'm spending hours trying to get invested into a story and characters, I better be won over. I spent nine hours on this game and the more I played the more I resented this game because it was nothing I expected. I'm not a furry, and I don't want to give off the "im judging you because you [i]are[/i] a furry" but the charming, witty reviews are what gave me the benefit of the doubt. 

All I want to say is, if you're on the fence about a game that will require hours of reading and possibly replaying to experience whatever it is youre looking for, make sure you at least know you'll enjoy some part of it. I'm sure it's probably fine if you're just looking for a casual game to play, but I can confidently say I wont recommend this game to a soul.

43244077.review:
Okay...
First, I need to get to the point where I can actually start describing anything properly :)
[b] But rest assured - no spoiler warning :3 [/b]

First of all, I played a bunch of VN's - especially the furry ones - and I guess at least all english translated gay-dating ones, so I've got some reference here to tell wether you should give this one a try or not. And you can already see, I highly recommend it - even if you're not really into homosexual or furry content I'd recommend you give it a try. 
The storyline has got some peaks you will always encounter in the same order but everything in between is up to your decisionmaking. Your choices matter - "well, of course my choices matter, it's a Visual Novel" you could say and I'd partly agree with you there BUT! - in this case I was kinda caught off-guard through my many playthroughs how impactful every single decision can be. Everytime you get to decide wether the protagonist does something it directly influences not even the way you get to the end of the story but even the end itself. Therefore you should try to play the story at least two to three times and every time, just take what you've learned about the protagonist and try to apply this in your next playthrough and you'll ultimately might end up in an end to the story that is not only quite longer than your average playthrough but also reveales a lot about the important characters, their motives, backgrounds and even feelings.

There are always moments in the story that give you somethign to think about, let you question not only the story or the fictional world you're playing through but also - like every good book or film should - makes you think about yourself. At least it did to me. If you immerse yourself in the Story you'll be able to question yourself and your decisions and this often left me in a brief state of - the fuck did just happen? - sometimes funny, sometimes awkward and sometimes even really depressing.

As I don't want to write a whole book about this game I think I'll just mention two other very neat features this game offers you: 
[olist]
[*]The game comes with a very emotional and beatiful composed soundtrack and even an Opening song + video! How awesome is that? :D
[*]This game uses a lot of words, names, places etc. that are just kept in the original language and provides a glossary that unlocks the entries describing the names, places, gods etc. as you progress through the game. But the thin that makes this actually awesome enough to mention it here is that, after I did some research and asked around at the university most of it is actually taken from the Taiwanese culture and mythology without changing much. Even basic principles are described one way or another without much missing or wrong information and that's actually a nice way to learn something you probably didn't know before.
[/olist]

Okay... so I guess everything else I could say at this point would take to much direct reference to the story and the characters which is the reason I'll just stop here and let you experience this game for your own. 
Here are just some good-to-know facts to help you get a short overview
[list]
[*]The game is a Visual Novel, containing not only a bunch of character sprites to show the speaking characters expressions while they are talking but also a lot of well sketched background images showing an approprite scenery to what's happening in your textbar most of the time.
[*]It also contains some animated scenes and lots of impactful sound effects, helping you to immerse yourself.
[*]Most of the characters are illustrated with even different types of clothing and expressions sometimes and characters present in a scene will be shown as long as they are there ( at least most of the time - I think I remember one scene where you're actually talking to someone but just got the background image but I couldn't recall where )
[*]you can play with your controller - I thought this might be worth mentioning as I found playing visual novels with my controler while making yourself comfortable and get something nice to drink (no really, remember to drink enough while playing video games or reading books!!) very nice.

As a sidenote I'd like to mention that there is in fact a NSFW version for this game but I highly, HIGHLY recommend to play the standart(Steam) version of Nekojishi - I've made my walkthroughs in both versions and the latter gave so much more depth to the characters and their feelings. It could be considered an option to play through both but.. imo it's not worth it - except your out for the yiff, then, well, go ahead [spoiler] but please don't be too disappointed if the NSFW content is just not that satisfying because of story reasons^^[/spoiler]

Now I hope you will have as much fun with Nekojishi as I had, because I definetly enjoyed this game. 
Thanks for taking your time reading this and have a nice day :)

This visual novel receives a 9.5/10.

The art is really good ans seeing the shades change on the character sprites depending on the scene, area and time of day is really well done.

The music is well written. Simple, yet brings out the tone ef the scenes perfectly. Never have I heard a piece and found it out of place.

The characters are well written, but I would've hoped to see more side (but that's a personal preference).

The story arcs are good, but there was a moment or two where I felt a bit lost. For example, why would a character act a certain way in only one scene when he doesn't in other similar scenes?

I find the story short, but it's very enjoyable and I'll surely re-read it again.

Overall, I love it and would've easily paid between 15-20$ for it. Luckily, there are paid DLC that can encourage us to help the DEVs behind this great game.

41728662.review:
Since I have finished the game for the umpteenth time, I think it's about time for a long overdue (and lengthy) review. Just as a fair warning this review may or may not contain spoilers, but I will do my best to make sure I do not to let any of the MAJOR plot points slip out, so if you want to avoid any possible spoilers steer clear. Without further ado let's get down to it.

[h1]Plot Summary[/h1]
The main plot of Nekojishi is somewhat linear and straight forward for the most part. You play and take the role of Liao; a young homosexual male college student ([spoiler]and furry[/spoiler]) who suddenly awakens to his hidden ability to see and communicate with spirits. However, these are not your typical spirits as they appear in the form of anthropomorphic animals. Now this game is obviously catered to a certain demographic and audience. If you're a furry and/or homosexual you're more than likely going to have a wet dream, if not then just take it for what it is with a grain of salt. But I digress. Along the line Liao is asked unfavorable requests from three feline spirits; his Guardian Tiger, Clouded Leopard, and Leopard Cat. [spoiler]These requests all require that Liao give up his college life and dreams, and become a Jitong/Oracle/Priest for one of the three cats[/spoiler]. As a result you are tasked with trying to find a way to appease these three feline spirits while trying to maintain your college life.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
As usual with most Visual Novels there isn't a whole lot of gameplay to be had. For the most part it's the stereotypical pick choice A, B, or C and then something happens. From there the game goes on long bits of dialogue before you get to the next choice option to make, and by long dialogue I mean a reaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaally long . However; not all of the dialogue in the game is bland as it offers interesting flavor text as well as adding more to the personality and likability of the characters. In addition some choices do lead to a few good laughs here and there.
As is tradition with Visual Novels this game has various different endings pertaining to the three characters; Guardian Tiger, Clouded Leopard, and Leopard Cat. In total there are about 12 endings (some of which are almost similar). However, unlike most visual novels it is not as straightforward as you may think to get some of the endings ([spoiler]the True Ending being one of them, and most difficult to get to without a guide[/spoiler]). Most of the endings require that you make very specific choices at certain points during the story, as well as how well you treat each of the three cats individually or all together. All in all if you’re going to jump into this thinking you can just romance one of the cats; sad to say, but you won’t be able to get the full experience the developers want you to have. Now I’m not saying that you can’t romance just one of the cats, but rather there is a specific route the developers want you to take to get the full enjoyment of Nekojishi.

[h1]Art and Music[/h1]
The visual aspect of Nekojishi is very appealing, it has a nice art style that is fluent and doesn't really stray far from its capabilities. However, the sprite work is somewhat lacking in regards to what most other visual novels are capable of. For the most part you will only see the same character sprites throughout the story with very little differences, save for a few facial expressions here and there. In order to compensate for this the character sprites move around the screen a few times to give a general idea of how the characters are interacting and behaving, be it with another character, their environment, or with what they are doing. In addition the bubble icon next to the dialogue window depicts facial expressions of the character talking which gives a better idea of how they are feeling.
Sprite work aside the CG’s are easily the most impressionable thing out of Nekojishi, the style is very distinct, impactful, and is very eye catching. However that being said the unique distinction between the sprite work and the CG’s does make a bit of a disconnect between the two. Because the artwork between the Sprites and the CG’s are different by miles sometimes it makes the player wonder if they are even still playing the same game. But nevertheless both styles still keep true to the original design of the characters.
As for the music if was fairly nice. It didn't stray too far from the general feel of the Visual Novel and it did a nice job on delivering the mood of what was currently happening.

[h1]The DLC/Epilogue[/h1]
In regards to the DLC epilogue, it was a little nice addition to the game. It gave a bit more content to the main story and was nice to see the characters develop even more. However, I was on the fence about the DLC  being a 1-2 hour long scenario (depending how long you take to read) that only has one choice option. The choice option really doesn't change much of what happens in the epilogue, but it does give more flavor text if you so choose to see them both before continuing on (but really you should be choosing them both anyway). The additional CGs that was included in the DLC was also a welcomed addition to the main story. It also gave much needed attention to the love scenes in the Public/Steam version of the game. However I really don’t think the Epilogue DLC is worth the money by itself. So I went ahead and got the Bundle DLC that came with the Chinese Voice Acting and I wasn’t disappointed. If you want to see the Epilogue and while getting your money's worth I highly recommend getting the Bundle pack. Sure it takes away from the charm of how the game originally started, but the voice acting does give a bit more depth to the characters in a way.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
All in all Nekojishi is a nice Visual Novel for what it is. It's a nice story with likable characters that all have their own strengths and faults, which also makes them likable to a certain degree. The supporting cast also adds more flavor when they are introduced over time and make the experience even more enjoyable. However, Nekojishi is still somewhat plagued with a few little grammatical errors here and there, but I was still able to enjoy it. Even the developers are doing their best to fix these errors which shows how much they care about their work. If you’re a grammar nazi then you probably won’t like this game; but like I said, take everything with a grain of salt. In regards to the Limited Version of the game, unless you are really thirsty for smut I highly recommend playing the Steam version over the Limited Version. The love scenes in the Steam version are more impactful in the feels department over the Limited version of Nekojishi. Overall a good story with lovable characters. I am looking forward to the continued development of Nekojishi as a whole.

Before I start actually talking about this game, let me just point out that I have a major bias for furries. Although, if you don't like furries you probably aren't interested in this game.

So I haven't gotten through the whole game yet, but let me walk you through the general plot real quick. You play as a taiwanese college student named Tian Liao Lin. One day, you start seeing these three cat man. There's your guardian tiger, a clouded leapord, and a leapord cat. Now these people are gods and you're a jishi, which is like a religious spirit medium thing. Now, you have your own plans for life. You want to become a professional dancer, but each of these three cats want you to use your spirit medium powers to dedicate your life to their temple. So they basically become your friends while you decide which one to go with.

Now, this game has three branches, one for each cat, each with multiple endings. I only went down the leopard-cat's branch (because oh my god is he adorable and like just my type) so I can't talk about the other branches.

But oh my god is it incredible. Beneath the cover of a furry dating sim, there's an amazing story and a ton of super interesting lore based around chinese and taiwanese culture. The ending I got was incredible with many different twists and stuff. It was a wild ride the whole way through.

Now, I will point out that this is the SFW version, and there is a more explicit version with cat-men sex in it that you can find at the nekojishi website. In this version, all the sex scenes are just replaced with kissing, but it doesn't detract from the story at all. 

TL;DR: If you like cat-men, I cannot reccomend this enough. If you don't like cat-men, it's a very interesting view into taiwanese culture and still worth a read. Absolutely reccomended.

41639678.review:
A very relaxing game, just perfect to forget your everyday worries and enter a world full of cheerful, charming and funny characters. I found myself genuinely enjoying it. It's true that the game is somewhat text-heavy. As a slow reader it took me an *hour* to reach the first decision the game gives you. But the later decisions were more frequent (I think ^^).

The translation is overall good. Not perfect and there are some mistakes, but that's nothing I can't forgive in a free game. The art style is nice and the way they move around made me laugh more than once.
The story however and the background info the game gives you, that's where Nekojishi really shines. I learned so much about Taiwan folklore, hot springs or - surprisingly enough - even the struggles of unknown artists.
The 3 feline characters fighting over who of them will win the main protagonist have very distinct personalities. There's a silent one, a cheerful and a third with a fatherly side on him ("dress well, it's cold today"). They are interesting enough in their own way.

Another suprise was the playtime. I expected it to be much shorter. I've *paid* for digital novels/dating sims in the past that weren't even half as long as this one. The slow pace emphasizes the fact that relationships (and many other things) take time, effort and work to grow. Granted, for some people it may be a bit too slow paced.

But the content is always there. New things happen, new characters and locations appear. There are different endings to discover and just when you thought you knew everything about one of the characters, you see things from another angle and learn so much more. 

So it's definitelly worth a try. I came here mainly for the beautiful anime/manga art style, since I'm not much into furry and even less into shonen ai, but I still had a nice time here.

41617601.review:
Please disregard my playtime at the time of writing this review. I played the Limited Edition outside of Steam. I recently purchased it on Steam to play the DLC.

You'll notice I don't write many reviews. That's because I only write them when a game leaves a heavy impact on me. And this game has done just that. I have never played either a dating sim or a visual novel, so I don't have a whole lot to compare this to, honestly. All the same, I loved this game. Truth be told, I was lukewarm on it at first. Played for an hour or two, then put it away for months. I came back to it and go a little further and--what's this? Suddenly it's dragging me in, making me all emotional. Not something I was expecting. This game tugged at my heartstrings, each ending heartwarming, heartbreaking, or, sometimes, both.

Gayness aside, I actually enjoyed building relationships with the cats more than any lewd stuff. Seeing how simple decisions could drastically change the story or any of the cats behavior toward "you," or Liao, whichever way you prefer to look at it. After I played as far as a couple endings, I couldn't stop. I had to see them all, so I just kept playing.

Ironically, I finished the final, true ending the day the DLC comes out. Just when I was desperate for more. Hooray!

Only cons I can see are: 1: English can be just a little off at times. Nothing significant--a duplicate word here, a typo there. A few things could be worded a little better. But really, it's a translation, and it's done quite well compared to most. I found it to be more than satisfactory.

2: Too short. I understand the base game is free, but had I known how much I would love it, I gladly would've paid money for a longer story. Thus my buying the DLC.

Also: Likulao is best cat.

41597812.review:
After releasing the DLC I have a LOT of things to say about this game because I feel like I must do that for the rest of people.
Good Points:
-Good Artwork coming from Takemoto
-Original Soundtrack
-Even the backgrounds are great
-The effects of this visual novel are better and more interactive than any other
-The choices for getting the good endings are not so easy to predict, so you have to replay it over an over
But now I think this is important: the story could be better, I mean I've been waiting for this game a lot don't think that I'm some kind of haiter or something. It's just that I was spenting a longer story than it was.
The only developed character is Senpai, he is more complex and the story practically focus a little more about him than the rest of the characters. Likulao is a good character too, I'm not gonna lie, but in the true route you won't have very chances to know more about him and I think that's kind contradictory when in the DLC looks like Liao knows everything that happen with him.
I started loving Tiger Guardian when Nekojishi was a demo, but when I could know him I couldn't stand him! He's contradictory in everything he says, at the end of the story you can't understand him at all. 

The story could have been better if it'd be longer, everything would have much sense and there's a lot of empty spaces even with the DLC.

Something else that I want to say, and this is about the DLC. Even so I like the game because the theme about taiwanse spirits is interesting and the Steam version is a lot better than the limited one, because the +18 are really excesed.
But this is a free game and a furry visual novel, there is a lot of furry visual novel that when they want to add something or fix something they just updated the game, for example Major/Minor. But putting a paid DLC so insignificance and without not so much meaning about the principal story is the worst. The only thing new about the DLC is the new outfits and the last part of the DLC for the story, is the only thing salvable. I just see this DLC an intent to make the story longer but without suceed. Even with this DLC you can get in the game new CGs but what the hell? For something like CGs they could just updated the game and done, there was NO necessary to spent money for something like that. They don't even need to put something like that when they gain money with the Nekojishi merchandise from their website.

That DLC is just a waste of money and I wouldn't recommend spent your money for that, you can live without that and you won't lose too much about the story. It's just an ambicious way to get more money about a furry game that got famous, that's all. It's not important at all. Don't make the same mistake as I.

With this I'm saying I don't hate the game, I like it. But the DLC theme it made me loss more respect that I had about the game.

41575802.review:
Nekojishi is quite an emotional game. I liked all 3 cat dieties and were consistently interesting throughout the 6-8 hours I had on my first playthrough (3 endings). Guardian Tiger who is very protective of Liao and wants him to come back to help the Jitong temple. Clouded Leopard who is not very great at social skills, poor at speaking Mandrin, and needs to help Wautai really badly. Finally, there is Leopard Cat who is very childish, loves Liao so much due to possession of Yan Shu-Shi, and needs help in Mialoi.

The game is pretty inocent in the begining, but I'd say your second choice is when the dialogue choices start to really matter and they increasingly matter the later you get into the story. You have happy endings and some spooky ass endings. You even have ones that are neutral or just only sad. The ammount of endings are large in this game. It gets pretty intense when you're long into it.

I'm a completely straight guy and all 3 cats made me feel for them and like them. I even had a man crush on Leopard Cat due to his ornery manniersms. I couldn't help it, he's adorable.

Overal, an amazing visual novel that recieved my respect.
