41055060.review:
First Impressions, You MUST try this game. I IMPLORE you, download this game, and play at least the first scene, if it’s off putting then you can choose to not play the game. BUT AT LEAST try.

Alright, on to the review.
So I review with 5 subjects, Gameplay, Story, Art (Music and Graphics), Enjoyment and Innovation/Bonus. Let’s start with game play.

Gameplay
This game... lacks in player control. I sometimes feel I go for long times without making a decision for the story and it gets boring. I can’t take too much off in this category because the story is amazing, and that is the real draw to a dating sim, I go deeper into that later. So really the gameplay can’t be given much merit because I also find that replaying many times (I go deeper into replaying in enjoyment) can get challenging when skipping through the text and suddenly the game stops so it can give me a full monologue where the words are slightly different then my other play through. Also, as I go into in enjoyment, a ton of the achievements are convoluted and hard to get because the game doesn’t even tell you what they are. To get all the achievements, I had to resort to a guide, not something I’m proud of but I had to do it. I give the gameplay a solid 0.9/2.0. Even with it’s flaws it still provides a game I feel I interact just enough in to consider it a game and not just a novel.
0.9

Story
Where this game lacks in play, it heaps on the story! Throughout the game you learn more about the characters and the whole magical situation you’re in. And the characters! On my original first play through, I didn’t see the whole picture of the game and almost immediately brushed off the characters as archetypes that you would select to go on dates with. Boy was I wrong! Every character feels real and have actual emotions that effect how I felt as a player. Next thing on the chopping block; the world. The game actually sets up a world of magical beings that are all inspired by Chinese and Taiwanese culture which really makes the game feel authentic. Last thing, the concept, I originally downloaded and played this game as a joke, considering I didn’t think I would enjoy a game with cat men in it, but as I kept playing I went looking for a reason to not like it, but I kept finding more things that I enjoyed. The story is quite pleasurable and makes me not want the game to end. This gets a good 1.9/2.0
1.9

Art
I like to look at graphics and music separately each worth one point. The graphics are adorable and don’t make me grimace the fact that I enjoy the cat people on screen, however, the full character models don’t seem to have enough expressions and almost sit there most of the time while their emotions play out in the corner. The close ups when the model zooms in a bunch, the pixels are easy to see, so that’s a minus. Still, the full pictures are adorable and I love them, but I wish there were more and that most of them weren’t locked behind very specific endings. The art is respectable but easy to see the flaws
0.6/1
The music is easily forgettable, but does provide a good background noise for when your playing, it does get repetitive when replaying, which gets annoying. The sound effects are perfectly timed and usually are used at appropriate times. I surprising enjoyed this game’s music when I think about that’s why it gets a 0.7/1.0 which makes the art have a 1.3/2.0
1.3

Enjoyment
Never did I think I would enjoy a dating sim with cat people, but I sure did. I don’t know what caught me, but this game continues to make me want to come back for more. I came back to it so many times I 100% completed it in 1 weekend. So yes, this game is highly addictive to the point where I can look past all the things that I didn’t like  about replaying the game. But this is also the kind of game that leaves you with a lot in your stomach, knowing that there is no more you can do to squeeze the content out of this game, yet you still will want more. However, is this not the greatest king of game? Either way I enjoyed this game probably more than I should have. I can only give it a 2.0/2.0 on this one.
2.0

Innovation/Bonus
This is the category in which I award points for things I liked about the game that don’t fall under anything else
+0.3 Inspiration from Chinese and other cultures to create game world
+0.2 Bringing me into a game genre that I would never have known before
+0.3 A surprising depth to a game that seems like it was a concept before a story
+0.1 Changed my opinion entirely from the start of the game
+0.5 How could I forget? It’s FREE
+0.2 Charm
+0.4 It made me feel actual emotions
I don’t have much more to say about the game without spoilers. So, I have to give this section a 2.0/2.0
2.0

Conclusion
Get this game. It is enjoyable to even the most hesitant, even though I critiqued the heck out of this game it has a charm I cannot shake off. I suggest completing this game all the way. So my final rating, with all the categories added up is...
8.1/10.0
(This is a good score, I am a very hard grader)

-Adam

41006915.review:
I honestly thought this was going to be another furry-bait dating simulator, but this has an amazing balance of story-telling and choice-making that it drives you forward to curiously want to know what all the possible outcomes are with each playthrough that you finish. And this game offers you several different endings for that reason. The characters each have an unique personality and backstory that makes the plot flow smooth and naturally as you progress, making it a very enjoyable read with every passing scene that you reach. It's amazing how many times the game went to such an unexpected twist from "silly and goofy cat guys doing shenanigans for the sake of filler chapters" to "their lives are at stake because of you and the subtle choices you've made that progressed or stagnated their relationship and trust so far". For some, the twists can be predictable and aren't as exceptionally exciting as you would expect, but for someone like me who was playing it in good faith and went through the story with a naive perspective, it can be enjoyable. They don't mention any topics that are too heavy or too complex that require precise and specific Shakespearian levels of intellectual reading to understand. The writing is simple, and anyone can read, play, and enjoy if they're looking for something light.

So if you like cat guys and a dating simulator who knows the balance of humor and drama, you should definitely give this one a try. If you're easily sentimental like me, it'll hurt. A lot. But it'll be something you're definitely not going to regret trying out.

Only critique is that unfortunately the MC is a big idiot, so good luck with that.

40927200.review:
Alright, like all things in this world, I jump into the game without  really knowing much about it. Visual Novels generally pop up for me on recommended because I've played a few and I like to look at any that seem interesting. This one... Is... Weird. 

I've never seen a game that was completely ingrained in Taiwanese culture, which immediately makes it more interesting in terms of a culture shock for me, but that's always good. So far, there have been only a couple of grammatical errors, but nothing to the level of say, the original Ace Attorney: Justice for All DS release in the US, so it's nothing horrible in that regard. 

The graphics are actually really pleasing to look at, and everyone is fairly well animated when they do. All the characters have nice vibrant colors and have distinctive expressions and body types. Same face has not been an issue in the game. Even if it's not necessarily my cup of tea, I might finish it, it's pretty well designed and I think most people that create visual novels or are planning to should give this one a shot because it's well made. 

I could comment on the story and the like, but it's more character driven than plot driven, so while the characters are nice, the plot is kind of lackluster and doesn't do much.

Just note, that the potential would be candidates seem to all be men. .I personally don't care, but I know some might. I don't think anything too risque will happen because we're on Steam. Though, I suppose you could get the other version.

40370829.review:
Okay, I started this one because it was free and the art is cute! Also reviews made it look like this was actually a PG-13 visual novel (it is--as long as you keep to the Steam version), which is important to me. I play VNs for the story and characters, and it can be tough to figure out if that's what you're getting sometimes :| I'm a PG-13, PG, or G kind of player.

I expected it to be short and cute/fluffy. It is, in large part, but I *didn't* expect to learn a bunch about Taiwanese religion/folklore/spirituality and about Taiwanese ethnic groups and tensions. Which was awesome! I love unexpected cultural knowledge. There's even a glossary where you unlock new terms as you play.

I was pleased to see that the fact one of the characters creeped me out was because he was actually intended to creep me out. A lot of the time, VNs will pass off a disturbing/emotionally clingy/brokenly needy character as 'cute,' and while there's some of that here, the character who comes off as creepy--is actually intentionally written as waving red flags, I think, given the way the story goes. And there's some nuance and twist in the "perfect" ending that I wasn't expecting.

It's *too wordy,* though. It really shouldn't be a 10-hour game, and with some editing for better pacing, it wouldn't be. There's a fast-forward feature, which does help a lot--but it also makes it clear how long some of the sections between choices actually are.

Overall, don't be scared off by it. If you like cute art, bonus cultural knowledge, and a story that goes a little bit beyond the blandness of many VNs, give it a go. Slog through the first long stretch with no choices, and it gets more interactive. You'll probably need a walkthrough to get the final "perfect" ending, which gives you the most information on what's motivating all of the characters.

40048168.review:
I was earnestly surprised and simultaneously a little disappointed by Nekojishi.

I came in with no expectations. I've played a few VNs, enough to have a pretty good grasp on the concepts. They often lean either toward being a game and offering a lot of player choice, or an interactive multi-path story; Nekojishi was a bit different, in that it played out its own story without much player input, and also that it offered an... interesting set of circumstances where you were required to complete specific paths to get specific endings. Some may call it gameful, I could stretch to call it a chore. It was fun, at least.

I managed to get 1/3 of the endings unintentionally while enjoying the story, and 2/3 (GT1-4, CL4, LC1-2) on purpose. At first, I wanted to see how interactive the endings were so I chose what I thought were the best answers, but these choices did not bear much fruit. Nekojishi forces you to replay to find each of the endings, and I feel like there's too much happening in the story and too many choices to have this few endings. If some of the paths were more lenient in your choices, it would be better. Additionally, some of the major plot points always happen regardless of the path you take, and sometimes it feels a little contrived.

I do enjoy however, what the story seems to try and teach. No matter the ending except for the "perfect" one, can you make everyone happy. The three main paths you can take with the characters allude to family (Guardian Tiger), self (Leopard Cat), and responsibility (Clouded Leopard), in my judgement. I saw some people define it slightly differently, but that's what I got out of it. I think the story is interesting enough for these reasons alone, and even if it's not the most believeable story, it's certainly entertaining.

I would recommend this to people that enjoy entertaining stories and mysteries, because after finishing the bad ends for LC I had more than a few questions that drove me to continue playing. If you don't care about the story and are just here for cute furry boys, the story will probably get in the way of that, in my opinion; but I'm not into any of the characters both physically and emotionally, so I can't speak on that. If you hate furries and the entire concept, you might still be able to enjoy the game if you like interesting stories. Otherwise, the story and characters are written well enough for a good few hours of free entertainment.

I would [b]not[/b] recommend this if you want a more cookiecutter VN romance experience, and don't want a lot of story or exposition getting in the way of your bear bara ball busting. If you're fine with the story and want some boy butt bumping, you'll need to get the [i]Limited[/i] version from their store, but it's clear it was not the focus and the story suffers from it in that version; a lot of exposition and emotional writing is simply wiped out. And even then, there's not much additional content.

Consider supporting the developers by buying the soundtrack or buying their game through their site, due to this overall being a quite high quality release. There are a few continuity, spelling, and grammar issues in the English translation at least, but they are few enough to be ignorable and don't really detract from the overall experience. They are also releasing patches to fix some of these problems.

40027698.review:
Get this game. It's free, it's charming, it's funny and it's heart-warming. The art is adorable and the story is pretty unique (in my opinion).

Now, I may be one of the other hundreds of reviews priasing this game - a game I bought on a whim because I love all cats, I love cat-men, and I absolutely LOVED the anime-style trailer for this game (which is the opening sequence). Right off the bat, I wasn't disappointed with this game. It's easy to use with a PS4 controller which was how I navigated through it while binging through all of the endings for one specific character.

Although I am disappointed it's not so much as a dating sim in the way of "you end up with whomever you choose" it's more a fate-deciding game when it comes to choosing how you will deal with your religion, your family, and three cat-god/spirits watching over you. (As well as approaching accepting your orientation, I suppose, and it was pretty great to find out this was basically an m/m dating sim.) I was super excited with every little twist and turn and surprising event in between and the characters alone (and all their art, ALL the art in general), so I generally can't recommend this enough.

There ARE a few spelling / grammatical errors but that's to be expect with a game that's being translated into English from another language. I was never confused as to what was being told to me however, so the errors are extremely minimal, more of a warning for anyone who expects this game to be 100% perfect with no flaws.

The biggest flaw of all, however is [spoiler] not being able to date Randolph or Ragoo [/spoiler] ...

10/10 recommending to everyone!

I am not a huge visual novel consumer, but I am a spiritualist, and the amount of spiritual culture in this story is amazing. The achievements are rather difficult to finish and require math and grids, and the translation isn't grammatically the best, but going through and getting all the endings really pulls the whole story together. 

The music? Fantastic. The personalities? Heartwarming. Definitely had a few twists and turns and a few endings in will have you questioning just what in the world is going on. Please - spend some time going through a couple endings before judging. 

There's a super handy skip feature that skips all dialogue you've already seen, but pauses at a decision or new dialogue. The autoplay feature is awesome too. 

All in all, this is going to be in my recommended list for a very long time.

39805130.review:
Some fundementals of the game: You, (Liao), are gay. There are gay beast boys. *insert assumption here*.
If that isn't enough, there is a 18+ version of this. So yeah...

That being said, the review!

[h1]The Good:[/h1][list]
[*][h1]The Art:[/h1]
The art in this game is absolutely fantastic. See the cover up there? That's basically the art level to expect. The only downside to this is that the scenery and the character assets are recycled throughout most of the game. There are some cute icons in the lower left corner to accompany the text and add emotion, but be prepared to see the same pieces of art again and again.
[*][h1]The Story:[/h1]
While the story has it's failures, it does a very nice job of getting the player/reader to emotionally connect with the characters. Whether you are gay or straight, the characters are endearing enough to keep you interested in their opinions of you.
[/list]
[h1]The Bad:[/h1][list]
[*][h1]The Endings:[/h1]
I can't properly discuss this part without spoiling the plot, but to summerize: The endings are quite rushed. You might finish the game and hardly be aware that it just ended.
Warning, spoilers!
[spoiler]An example of what I mean by this is the first two 'leopard cat' endings. In the middle of some dialouge, you are struck by a car. Later you have your soul stollen and the game ends. I am not making this extra brief. There is hardly any dialouge in this whole conclusion, and the ending is incredibly frustrating. There are other endings, some of which are much better executed, but be warned, these are the areas that the story breaks.[/spoiler]
[/list]
[h1]The Ugly:[/h1][list]
[*] *Cough cough* gay furry trash *cough cough* ... but wait... if I enjoyed this game... what am I? O_O... OwO...
[/list]

Seriously though... if this game cost 10 bucks, it'd still be worth it. It's free, so unless gay furries make you hurl, play it.

The beast-bois are cute and their personalities really grew on me, but there's just too much to slog through. 39228919.review: I came into the game unsure of what to expect since it was reccomended to me by my friend, I think he saw it as a way to poke at me for spending too much time writing my own novels and not going outside. At first I was utterly confused but as I went along it gained that one aspect that I find most games lack these days: A connection. Sure, theres the appeal and attractiveness of said main characters, but I am meaning a deeper connection. For example, while the other two bickered and battled each other on a dayly basis, Likulau was just there, and was always there when the protagonist needed him to be, just helping him as best he could despite not understanding completely some scenarios. There were ups like the dancing session with him and downs such as when he started trying to take the power from Liao, but all in all the game developed a connection for me to the character specifically. This is just one playthrough from the limited edition, and I have yet to finish every ending, but as far, each one of the 3 felines has things that I can relate to and sympathise with. It's not a game for the unsympathetic or speedrunners the communities have generated today, and it is more a game where you look at the decisions you can make, and realise that unlike many games that have things work out for everyone, your decisions have consequences. And some of the decisions can kill you inside when you realise what you have done. All in all 10/10 for the execution and plotline, but 7/10 for some things like story flow, as sometimes thee dialog doesn't quite feel like it flows well about halfway into the game, but that is just me being a flow critique. 9.5/10 overall for this quite frankly great game that had me in literal tears at some points when I realised what I had done when I did something wrong and I couldn't fix it.

39191127.review:
[i] (don't be confused by my ingame time. I played the "Limited" version from their official site) [/i]

So, Nekojishi is an interactive graphic novel in which a young college student, whose name is Liao, suddenly gets the ability to see "Guardian Tigers" and other gods and spirits. Because I don't want to spoil anything I wont go into the story further.


[h1] Pro: [/h1]
[list]
    [*]Very well written charackters
    [*]Relatable main charackter (but that may be just me, because I'm [i] weird [/i] too)
    [*]Nice visualization (of the scenery and charackters)
    [*]VERY cute art
    [*]Nice story telling 
    [*]Very creative
    [*]Easy Language
    [*]Nice flow of Music
    [*]Nice mood 
    [*]Adjustable text speed
    [*]Very simple animations that don't distract you reading but will give some kind of depth and live to the story
[/list]

[h1] Con: [/h1]
[list]
    [*]Some spelling mistakes (but it's a minor problem, it doesnt interfere with the fluidity of reading or the mood)
    [*]Musik sometimes stops (so u are left in silence until u reach a point that triggeres it again)
    [*]Confusing ending (if u get the "wrong" one, but I played again to get another ending and that cleared my confusion)
[/list]

[h1] Things I dont know where to put: [/h1]
[list]
    [*]Multiple endings (I'm always afraid to do something [i] wrong [/i], but thats just me beeing 
anxious)
    [*]Somehow I feel empty after finishing the story, although i have so many thoughts in my head. I dunno I'm weird.
[/list]
(Probably forgot something i wanted to say)

Yeah thats it. So my conclusion is that I really enjoyed reading this novel and would definetly recommend it to others. (wait didn't I just do that?)
So I would suggest you  just give it a try because its very well made. And what can you loose anyway, right?

Thanks for reading and have a nice day,
Muclar

However this game is far from everything else I played. I felt a strong connection with the Guardian Tiger and instantly became obsesed with trying to get every of his good endings. Later I went back and tried to uncover the sotry and its actually amazing, granted you have to like the other characters that...you may not like but hey its worth it. If you want a visual novel that can keep you addicted and trapped in the story and easily, so easily fall in love with the characters this game is worth a shot for you. The story is well developed and written out, it almost doesn't feel like a game. 
Sidenote: (Guardian Tiger) Lin Hu is bae. He's mine!

You - just an ordinary college student who suddenly has the power to see three "feline spirits" 
Each of them has their own problems and they need your help , but you can't help all of them , only one
The game has a lot of options for you to choose in order to progress  , it won't be so easy to pick , get them right and you might get to the good ending , if not , you might get the bad ending instead , so be wise

Overall , just another beautiful masterpiece in this world
11/10

I've played this game many many times ( include direct way and indirect way ( watch other youtubers play Nekojishi with acting )) and still enjoying . I have to say that I highly recommend this game because :

-Soundtrack : One of the strongest point of this game , the melodies are totally suitable with the scenes around and harmonize with the feeling of the character , feel more relax when 3 Big Cats joke around ? feel more depressed when you got a bad ending , well then , you will get more and more with a great sountrack too . 

- The story is rich , your decisions , your choices will lead to the ending , heart-warming or get depressed ,  also describes how plentiful of Taiwan's cultures and traditions are . Well , honestly i have a feeling to travel to Taiwan now , consider it as a goal for me in the future .

- This game is FREE . I still can't believe it ...  I feel like voluntary to buy Nekojishi's products and donate and yes I did .  i think its worthy . Expect to purchase more from the Nekojishi's Store to support the DEV .

Overall : 10/10 
I love both Lin-Hu and Likulau , they definitely are kind of man to love that you are looking for , but if i have to choose one *shy*, definitely Lin-Hu ...

Done playing game , finished all the endings and found all Glossaries , achievements , what to do ? Currently , i will stick to the Steam's Nekojishi Community Hub to read more about the reviews , art work and new discussions as well as comment , watch Nekojishi, Morenatsu , Repeat , Lagoon Lounge on youtube, played by various youtubers recently and the main point is waiting for the miracles from the DEV .

38250331.review:
The first time I lay eyes on this visual novel for some reason I had a flashback of how another similar "furry" setting game which was Major/Minor, I initially thought it was going to be this cheap cringe yaoi game that will not last and it will go to the rest of the piles I have seen it happen that have a similar premise. Yet despite my thought, I was curious what it was about and the trailer actually hooked me up to try it especially the music, I would not mind buying the soundtrack of it to support the developers because this game is something. I'm not exaggerating by saying this but this might be my top visual novel game in 2017 (not the best game ever in 2017). What I mean is this game had left me in an emotional spiral plus the game Oneshot that I felt. When I heard the game Doki Doki Literature will have the same emotional tug that I felt I refuse to play it cause I heard it pulls your emotion so hard, though I will have an update of the review of what I think now Doki Doki Literature when I finish watching a LP. 

[h1]Presentation[/h1]

I absolutely love almost everything it presented this visual novel, the music, artstyle, characters and story very well written. Keep in mind yes it's still a yaoi game, but I guess it does not feel that is in your face type of game where the protagonist does a giggity move on the beastmen....weeell maybe senpai but don't worry the romance is subtle including the protagonist's lust for beastmen. I love the art style, the cultural setting which the game takes place in Taiwan, heck even their mythology are represented well even share a glossary book for people to learn some terms. The characters are pretty convincing even the protagonist has some form of realism to it, he is just a college student trying to have a normal life and three beastsmen shows up and stuff happens I can't spoil it. I know what you may be asking and yes why did I say this game pulls your heart around, well for one thing is because you'll get invested your characters more as you dive deeper into the story. Another thing is I can't tell you all of the plots as much as I really want to because I would ruin the experience for you. The only description I will make from this game, but only because to save you the heartache to perhaps prepare you for what is to come, but if you absolutely want to play it blind well go ahead and play it now. [spoiler]This game is depressing despite the cutesy look, maybe in hindsight I did not look at the glossary to put one and two together. The whole experience of the three beastmen at first was nice but it goes down deeper as you take different endings to see how it makes sense each ending represent the path you chose.[/spoiler]  I will say just for personal preference that if I have to pick the three beastmen base on looks, backstory and character I would choose 1.Clouded Leopard, 2.Leopard Cat/Senpai, and 3.Guardian Tiger.

[h1]Wait this isn't right?[/h1]

This game may be a really great piece of work that I will give major kudos to the developers who made this game and hope they will continue their work in the future, but I encounter a common problem that visual novel games does and is spelling errors. They are easy to spot and sometimes can be a bit distracting. What is distracting that almost ruin the experience is some scenes plays out in the wrong moments, mainly in the 18+ patch.

Yes, I played the 18+ version of the game which here is a tip, please play the vanilla version because if you want to have a good experience story the vanilla plays the story better, if by playing with your *ahem* joystick then sure go ahead though I have an issue even on the vanilla version. The main is plot issue both the 18+ and the vanilla, though the 18+ is much worse in time placement on the "juicy" scenes. I know what you may be asking and not just because is an 18+ version, it does not mean to make the story less convincing to attach the characters. I have played Nekopara and other visual novels with 18+ patches for.....research, but this one is missing an important story element and is time placement. What I mean is, there are major scenes that play like you feel you should be taken serious but instead  it place the X-scene in an odd moment which ruins the moment and character of the protagonist...especially how the protagonist portrayed in some moments with the beastmen which makes me dislike him. It kills some moments and even made me uncomfortable of how some of the scenes play out instead of something that comes naturally like in Nekopara (you'll see what I mean if you decide to play that version.) It kills the mood and makes the protagonist less likable and makes you feel some wtf moments in times where it should not be placed in that scene atleast not yet. 

The vanilla version brushes up the developement of the characters better especially the protagonist, though one ending still made me feel odd due to the atmosphere it gave out which I don't know if is me but if you find it please tell me if you agree with me on this. ([spoiler]is the true ending[/spoiler]) Perhaps is because the game trying to remind me is still a yaoi game but eh, it could have brushed it a bit better, the rest didn't affect me too much especially the ending it left me satisfied.

[h1]Yay Forever Beastmen![/h1]

This game I enjoyed the experience it gave me and for how much it left me of an impact of it. This game deserves a 9/10 and for the 18+ 8/10, for a free game with good simple decision route though I will say some of the multiple endings are sort of tricky to find each ending. You will replay this game multiple times which will come somewhat tiring when hearing the same dialogue, but when opening a new path you will stop and enjoy some of the additional dialogue it adds to the story. I hope you will enjoy these few hours of reading as much as I do because at the end of this game you will start questioning your orientation........enjoy. >:)

So a friend recommended this game in hopes of introducing me to a very "mature" and "heart-warming" story in the form of a visual novel. I've already played through Ace Attorney, so I'm basically a visual novel professional, right? Not knowing what I was getting into, I downloaded this game (free for me at least) plus the additional "18+ adult patch" that was sent to me by my friend. I'm very mature AND an adult, if I do say so myself, so I thought the patch would be a great addition to my experience! Noticing some of the pictures & trailers on the steam page, I focused in on the fact that many of the tiger men were buff and dressed in particularly "revealing" attire! This is of no concern to me, however, for I have read through all 5 parts of Jojo's Bizarre Adventure! I thought "maybe this will be something along the lines of Jojo but crossed with Tony the Tiger!" I loved frosted flakes as a kid, so this was a HUGE upside for me.

What I would soon discover is that these characters weren't merely JUST buff tiger men having some fun! They were furries! I already had my suspicions that some of my friends who recommended this to me were furries since they always seem to have profile pictures displaying anthropomorphic animals in seductive poses, but this was what opened my eyes completely to such a revelation! However, I don't know much about furries in the first place. Maybe they're just members of a friendly community that happens to adore animals! I have an adorable cat named "oreo", for example. In that case, I can absolutely see why they might like these types of games!

Powering through many lines of dialogue I really couldn't due to being wired on "Earl Gray Bergamot-Flavored Black Tea", I eventually discovered that the scenes in this game were no ordinary display of friendship! These "tony the tiger" doppelgangers had sexually explicit relationships together! I couldn't believe my eyes, my purity was draining by the second! I'm already gay for Griffith from the hit manga "Berserk", but this was way too much for even me to handle! After force-closing my game just to get a grip on my sanity, I pondered for a bit. Is this what all those 'furries' on my steam friend list are getting into when I see them playing games like "Amorous?" It's just not right!

I decided to do what was right for the whole Steam community! I reported my "friend" who recommended this game to me to Gaben himself and scheduled him a surprise therapy visit (I covered the expenses out of generosity)! You cannot do this to tigers! If I ever went to an arcade with a tiger, it'd surely rip into my jugular within 1.5 seconds, even if I was given a head start to run away from it! So why in this game does the tiger hug me when I approach it? And why must we see them so in such "seductive" and "alluring" poses when talking to each other?!?!?

I hope you're all happy with what you've done to me! This is not something you send your "friends", you furries!

38191452.review:
TL;DR If you liked Morenatsu you will absolutely like this as well.

Nekojishi is an absolutely wonderfully crafted visual novel featuring same-sex male relationships between a man and beast-mean (better known as furry) characters. Each choice contains weight to it and watching the reactions to the other characters based on each choice makes you want to replay the scenario later to see what happens when you choose differently. Not to mention the endings are emotional roller coasters that really play with your emotions, especially if you get one of the bad endings and makes you want to try for a better ending. The characters are memorable and enjoyable, leaving you with a sense of guilt anytime you disappoint one of them. The music is very well done and heavy amplifies the feeling in major scenes. Despite having heavy moods sometimes, it still manages to find appropriate times for moments meant to give you a chuckle and doesn't lose sight of the spirit aspect to the beast-men. The only minor complaint I can think of is the translation errors, but after having done about half of the endings, I only had 1 time where I was unsure of what they meant to say. All in all, if you want a gay furry VN, Nekojishi will do more than satisfy you

38183971.review:
Takeing a step back from the whole "furry romance" the writing isn't all that bad, it has a few issues with translations as the game is orginally made in Twaiense( i think), but its actually well-devolvped with each character evolving as you make choices: (bit of a spolier) Many choices actually leave you with a sense of incompletness and longing, because most of them will give a bad-end if you chase after certain characters while commiting to certain decisions....

The writing also deserves some congrulations because instead of it being directly made on the romance scene, it also is realistic in the aspect that if you were faced with these situations you would freak out + not be able to make them realistically. Fruthermore the game doesn't look track of the whole "spirit" portion, which is a nice touch! 

The music: Music quality is nice! There's  a lot of tradtional insturments in the more tradtional areas, and a LOT of piano(Which is a good touch considering its a visual novel!

Issues: While the game does settle on some heavier themes, the majority of it is a visual novel(not Doki Doki) so those themes kind of fall into the background, while choosing your path falls into the foreground
Fruthermore, the game is built around it being explecity furry + gay, so there's literally no female character whatsoever'
Barely even mentions Liau's(you) mom, and doesn't go into his personal life at  all'
The game falls flat on facial expressions a lot, while it has a nice little "emote" portion next to dilaouge, the models don't shift very much'
The game is REALLLY pretty, with a few scenes being full on CG, and others being more hand-drawn; regardless some of them are really breathtaking, and with dilaouge to help you along with picturing more of the detial, it comes off really well!
Overall: This game does deserve the high praise that it received! It's well crafted with a lot of love from the creators despite its obvious fan-base being geared toward the furry community. I do recommend' (also the opening is like a fucking anime so that's cool as shit)

38146930.review:
Good things:
- The 3 main characters were all very well-developed. They grew on me gradually., and also develop relationships with each other. The contrasts between their characters were more complicated than the too-common manga "the crazy one, the smart one, the tomboy" etc. choice. Each of these charcters is both appealing and annoying, in different ways.
- The fast-forward (hit CTRL) is VERY useful!  Wish I'd noticed it earlier.

Bad things:
- The opening feels like a typical manga "loser guy suddenly has a harem of hot babes competing over him" scenario.  It gets better quickly, but it's bad to have the opening feel so generic.
- Characters never ask two crucial questions: why [spoiler]can't Leopard Cat fix his own temple or get somebody else to do it, and why can't Spotted Leopard find somebody else[/spoiler].  Liao is trying to make his big decision without getting the information he needs to make it.
- There was no 'G|PG|R|X' rating anywhere--no way of knowing whether I was going to see pictures I didn't really want to see. It turns out there's a paid version that has such images, so you're safe if you don't pay. But nothing on the Steam store webpage or in the game said anything about it.
- The English translation had extremely bland, just-the-facts writing. The writer or translator needs a can of "Show, don't tell."
- The plot points, where you get to make a decision, were chosen for game mechanics reasons--as places to adjust the emotion scores for each cat--rather than for story reasons!  So you get to decide whether to go on a date with a cat or not, but get no say in some of the most-important decisions your character makes, like [spoiler]whether to kill someone[/spoiler].  The entire story is framed as you deciding between the 3 cats, [spoiler]but you never get to, at least not directly![/spoiler]  It's very weird that you have to figure out the game mechanics and beat them over weeks of story time just to accomplish something that your character could do with a few words.
- This is made worse by your narrator-character being a total wuss, so he sits back and watches things unfold a lot of the time.  Seriously, Liao is annoying.
- The plot points are VERY far apart. We're talking hitting the space bar over a thousand times between decision points sometimes.  Spend less time painting backgrounds and more time writing dialogue, guys.  Personally, I think this game would have benefitted if each separate location were an adventure-style world, so you could type commands like "TALK TO LEOPARD" or "DANCE", and feel like you had some control.
- I wish that the controls let you set the printing to be instantaneous.  Even the fastest speed is quite slow.

38049748.review:
[h1]TLDR; Nekojishi is a wonderfully written visual novel with endearing character design, plot, and it's free! 10/10[/h1]

Nekojishi is good not because of giant cat husbandos and stunning visuals(Though it certainly helps), but because it develops its characters and makes you attached to them. I initially downloaded Nekojishi with the expectations of a cheesly written romance novel with no real direction, but I was pleasantly taken aback as to how fleshed out and well [i]good[/i] it truly was. 

The gist of the story is that we follow Liao, a college student living a hum-drum life who is granted the power to see cat spirits who all happen to need his help in one way or another. It's here where the player must guide Liao down a path with one of these spirits and make choices that are difficult, funny, saddening, and the rest of the whole nine yards. It's these choices that make the game particularly awesome only because the writing is so good and it makes you consider the shades of grey within' each scenario, sort of like Night In the Woods. 

As for the visuals? There's very little to be said beyond stunning, one can tell that heart and soul went into the making of this novel. All in all, I would highly recommend this to anyone as an endearing story worth remembering and playing many times over for all the different paths and endings.

37922580.review:
This visual novel is great tbh.

You have to be very open minded because this does take place in Taiwan, and deals with a lot of folklore from that region.  A lot of people leave reviews after only looking up the "True Endings", but I feel like you really need to experience all of the routes to really beat this game to the fullest, as even the other routes provide details that you might overlook by just skipping straight to the true ends.  I highly suggest giving the game a few run-throughs with your own choices to see where it leads you, and then look up a guide when you feel like you've tried everything.

I also have to say that the 18+ version is very different in how the story is told, as the steam version is way better plot-wise and emotion-wise since the lewd version is pretty much just for the CG scenes.  Basically all the endings are rewritten to force you into lewd situations, while in the SFW version it's way more emotionally written with more respect towards the overall story.

You can't really talk about this game without spoiling anything, so I'll just say that I liked all 3 of the cats in their own ways and all 3 had ending routes that I enjoyed.

37912147.review:
It's rare to find a game which can play with your emotions like this one can. At first some people may pass this off as a basic interactive story about dating furries, but as you get deeper into the game the plot can take many twists and turns, it becomes far more deep and will have you thinking of the characters in a variety of different ways depending on your choices. You may come to care for each of the characters, you'll feel sorry for them, feel happy for them, feel disappointed, hopeful, and more. The writer does a fantastic job fleshing out the characters in ways which makes you like them without giving away the whole truth behind them.

There are many endings in this game, some good, some bad. One of the things which made me play through he game multiple times is that I wanted things to be better, to make the right choices so everyone could be happy, and each ending made me see the characters in a completely different light.

The art in this game is quite good, though except for changes in facial expressions you'll only ever see the characters in the same few poses through the whole game and it will leave you wishing for something different after a while.

The beautiful music helps to enhance parts of the story really well, the soundtrack is one of the main things which will play with your emotions, the happy bouncy tune when characters are being silly makes you feel good. The slow soft tunes in some of the more sad and serious moments make you feel sorry or sad for the characters, and it will tug at your heart strings more as you get deeper into the story.

I understand that this type of game may not be everyone's cup of tea, especially if you're not into the whole furry scene, but I would highly recommend it to people who do find these kinds of games fun. You'll have a good time reading a well written story and will enjoy seeing where your decisions take you.

37899825.review:
This game has too little gameplay and too much handholding.

Everyone will have their own opinion regarding the characters themselves. (Some will love them, some will think they are one-dimensional carboard box cutouts with all the personality of a baloney sandwich), -but that is not my issue with this game.

There is no game! 

After playing for 3 hours I have made... 5 choices? Maybe? Almost all of this game is clicking through the next round of banal chatter that is highly instance specific. Very few of my choices feel like they allow me to get to know the characters better or understand their motivation, and the ones that are supposed to are incredibly cut and dry.

These types of games are all about choice and getting involved in the world. You can't do that when you can't control the majority of the choices (or, at least, you can't do it as well as you could otherwise).

The artwork is nice, especially for a free game (truly, you cannot argue with such a price), but the 'gameplay' is simply frustrating and far too limited.


I'll recommend a pass on this one, but I appreciate the artist's effort and wish the creators well in their next game.

37809450.review:
As much as I am not a fan of visual novels, Nekojishi convinced me that this genre have some hidden gems.

Actually, the only one thing that make me played this novel were characters, cat characters more precisely. They are very nicely drawn and look truly friendly from the very beginning. 

Technically, this game does not have tons of graphic content. There are few characters that doesn't change much during gameplay and several backgrounds that might not be the most beautiful pictures I have ever seen. Even though it is visible that devs tried their best to make it attractive - characters slides (which imitates their movement) and, in some points, lightning changes giving backgrounds and characters different hue.

The most important part of visual novel is a story, and the story of Nekojishi is truly solid. There is lot of fun, but also sadness and uncertainty in this game. Choices truly matter and they are not always easy. If you play visual novels for sexual content, you will be surprised how little amount of it Nekojishi includes. Especially that the game is about big furry cats. It rather focuses on feelings of the characters and their relations between each other.

As much as long texts of visual novels make me usually bored, it was absolutely different in case of Nekojishi. It took me long hours to get to the first ending and I was surprised how easy it was to read. I will definitely try to reach rest of endings in the future.

So far... I can recommend this game, even for those, who are not into visual novels.
And one of the reasons why they should try Nekojishi is because it is for... free. Actually this is the biggest surprise since it is the best visual novel I have played so far.

37601118.review:
I love this game, but to clear the air as a disclaimer, I am COMPLETE FURRY TRASH so what I'm going to say will be probably preetty biased.
The fact of the matter though is that the game itself is pretty impressive, especially in terms of, specifically, furry visual novel projects. The english translation is decent, the story is good, and the characters are wholly likeable. The competition for best boy in this game is definitely real, and finding the path to all good endings is, for the most part satisfying.
My biggest gripe about the game is that the characters, especially the protagonist himself, follow specific tropes and stereotypes that define them. These traits are subverted or played upon a few times at most, but let's be real- it's a game about unreasonably attractive cat man spirits and that's why you're playing the game in the first place, right?
The most impressive factors to this game, to me, is the consistent, strong art style as well as the awesome character design. The three cats are designed each quite beautifully, balanced well with their personalities and stories, and the art for particular scenes is of notable quality (so yes, gay eye candy. Which you probably should be prepared for if you're playing this game). While this doesn't completely bleed over to the small cast of guest characters that appear, they're written well enough to fit the mold of the world, which in itself is cute and kind of fun.
As a follower of pretty much all things furry and creative, I'm happy to see a game tackle a furry dating sim with as much ambition and talent that I haven't seen from asian creators since the mid 2000's with the Morenatsu project, and I would definitely love to see and support more games like this in the future.

[i]*frame freeze*[/i]

Yep, this is my life now, playing furry visual novels at 3AM in the morning, with a couple important assignments that are due. You're probably wondering how I ended up in this situation.

You see, this conundrum begun on a bright sunny sunday afternoon. I was Netflix n chillin', catching up on my favourite anime, Bojack Horseman, while browsing the interwebz. Could not have gone any better. While scrolling Reddit, out of the corner of my eye, I saw something. I see some familiar words. I quickly scrolled up and lo and behold, I see a post about this game being greenlit. Suddenly, I had a fuzzy feeling inside, and deep down I knew that, I can see something in this game, but I don't what it is. Was it potential? Possibly. I waited patiently, like a loyal doggo, checking if there's any dev update on Twitter, this Steam page, trying not to forget this game, and it's release date. In the end, my enthusiasm died out, and the wait has taken it's toll on me.

Some months pass, and it's already November 2017, time flies, I told myself. Things were quite good, but I had not much personal time. As a result, I had forgotten about my life online. But today, today is the day that changed everything. I was just checking Reddit, and I notice a familiar name. [i]Nekojishi.[/i] And it has just been released on Steam. Then it all comes rushing back to me. [i]The furry cat game.[/i] I get that same fuzzy feeling from last time, but it's greater. My inner-furry has been awoken. I rush to my computer, navigating swiftly pass open Word documents, PDF files, Firefox windows, handy text files filled with copypasta, Discord and finally reached my destination; the Steam app. My fingers raced across the keyboard, typing the game's name, and Steam, as always, knows me well enough to suggest it in the quick search results. Clicked it, hit 'Play' and waited some more for it to download. It's as if I haven't waited long enough. 

After the painstaking waiting, I saw the game's icon on my desktop. It seemed as though it was gleeming, standing out from the monotonous-looking desktop. I thought to myself for a while before playing the game, was it worth waiting this long for a simple game like this? I had conflicting thoughts, and started the game, not expecting much, maybe even begining to regret my decision to dedicate this much time thinking about it. But as soon I saw the charcters in their full personality(or shall I say, fursonality) I was blown away by how cute they were. 5 seconds later, I found out that, yep, it's the furry effect that's going on, making me embrace it. I play some more, adore the characters even more, take a look at the time, and decide to say bye to my husbandos for now. 

Proceeded to have some emotional & existential thoughts about how I will never meet anthro kitters or anthro anything in my life. Accepted this world is cruel and decided to find a way to express my feelings. I studied online on how to meditate. I meditated, imagining what a world with anthro creatures will be like. I researched on lucid dreaming, in an attempt to get closer to my husbandos. Feeling spiritually enlightened, I decided to write a review about this wonderful game, which was probably the easiest method to begin with. But with my last strengh of power, I typed away for ages to create a perfect review, which goes like this:

[b] 10/10 would play again for furry husbandos [/b]
[b] 10/10 would have an existential crisis again about furry husbandos never existing [/b]

TL;DR:  found this game greenlit, forgot about it, months later, found this game, played it, loved it, got emotional, threw me into a state of depression and distress, seeked spritual enlightment, expressed feelings 10/10 would recommend this game.

37378928.review:
Here I am again writing another review... Let's get to it then.

[h1]A Brief Summary of Nekojishi[/h1]
In this game you start as Liao, the human who just wants to live his college life.
Liao suddenly starts seeing these feline spirits, Guardian Tiger, Clouded Leopard, and Leopard Cat.
I would call it as "Invasion of home" since they just decided to live at Liao's Dorm, can't even call it a home for four...
Guardian Tiger or Lin Hu aims to protect you and to come home after his graduation.
Clouded Leopard or Likulau desperately wants Liao to be his oracle.
Lastly, Leopard Cat wants him to restore a temple.
Liao sees them as these handsome furries because of his... "Doujins" and Fantasies...

[h1]About this game[/h1]
This game is a visual novel that has multiple endings.
The characters of this game are memorable and also mostly composed of furries.
There are some grammatical errors in this game but that shouldn't bother much.
The game contains a glossary for people who don't understand a word or phrase.
This game might turn you into a Gay Furry...
Psst... There's another version that has 18+ Stuff ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°).
So that's about it I think.

[h1]My Review[/h1]
For me, I would gladly rate it highly since I enjoyed its story and the characters are just memorable to me.
The storyline and the ending was just enough to make me tear up.
Everytime I made a decision that would hurt a someone will just make me depressed.
I got so invested to these characters so much I forgot to leave my home for a week...
The game's manipulation of emotion is just great.

I would rate this game as 87 / 100.

Also Likulau is hot. ♥♥♥♥♥

Finally I'm done writing this review...

[h1] TL;DR: Best Dating Sim of All Time, in fact, I wouldn't even consider it a dating sim. [/h1]  


     I was never interested in the dating sim genre. However, this one appealed to me, for personal reasons. I can't give away any information about the story; for this truly is a masterpiece. But I will say that this has one of the most amazing, no, the most amazing and heartfelt stor(ies)y I have ever seen. That whole "No, the most" stereotypical praise for a work is so common, but I cannot find any other words to describe this game. It is the interstellar of dating sims, if you understand. (Another great thing you should see [movie]) And before I begin, it's 6:00 am. I've been playing it since 1:00. As I first downloaded it in my own self-pity and cringe for what I thought would be a cheesily written cringe-fest. I was wrong. Since I have been up for so long, I will try to make these paragraphs meaningful, but not exhausting on the already overworked human-mind.

     There are spelling and grammatical mistakes, but PLEASE, and I do not write in all caps ever, but PLEASE do not let this deter you from the game. All grammatical and spelling errors are easily grazed over and mentally corrected by the mind; also posing no immersion breaking after-effects. Whether there errors or not, you have to give the game the benefit of being just released, and free.

     The writing is phenominal, as aforementioned above. I have no idea how long this game was in development, something I will look into, but I know this took love and dedication to write. There are at least 70 paths you can take in this game. I took me 4.2 hours (with mistakes and reloads [I got some endings I didn't like at all.]) to finish one ending. I will continue playing this game until I have all (23?) achievements. There are some things the main character (you) does that I didn't find relatable and would piss me off, especially in some my endings with [spoiler] Cloud Leopard HES SO FUCKING HOT OMGOMGOMG [/spoiler] The ending I actually took with him was very mentally [strike] and physically [/strike] satisfying.

     The characters are lovable and [i] will [/i] grow on you. Like them or not [i] they will [/i]. I cannot express how amazing this game is. Developers, if there is any place or way I can financially benefit you, I need to know. This game is too good for you to not be paid for it. I don't care if this is/was a passion project, I truly want to give back for what you have given me and so many others to come. 

     [h1] Final Verdict [/h1]
[b] This game is not your usual dating sim. Like a lot of other games, this is a shining star. And it now holds a special place in my heart. Please play this, once. You might even become a furry, I guess. But you're still a human in the game, what do I know? [/b]


     [h1] UPDATE; IMPORTANT [/h1]
     After looking around, (really not hard, really.) I've found the developers' websites. https :// nekojishi . tw/ (spaced just in case Steam freaks the fuck out about links.) You can donate twn dollars and get the [b] NSFW [/b] version (It's limited edition, so get it now! [excuse my use of exclamation marks, I have always found them unnecessary and rambunctious]) Or get the [b] NSFW [/b] version free, they're just nice, I guess. I donated already. I recommend you do too.

36989296.review:
Come on. What's not to like about cat gods? These guys don't even knock stuff off your desk.

They actually can't touch most of the stuff, or maybe they would?

Really though, it's a cool visual novel with some mature moments, some funny moments, and pleasant music that complements each of the scenes. A lot of the English could use some polishing, but the script is still readable and doesn't detract toooooo awful much from the flow of the story. I like the fact you can save on any screen and quit on a moment's notice if you have to step away. My only feedback on that is to offer more save slots than what is currently offered; there are so many options, it's tempting to save a lot. There are multiple endings too, which gives this story a good amount of replayability.

The artwork is pretty phenomenal and greatly enhances the story, too. It's clean, polished, and professional-looking. You can even go back and see the art itself in the gallery after you initially find it in the story.

I hope this team continues to develop more stories. They're really off to a fantastic start with Nekojishi!

36855792.review:
Whether you're a fur, gay, whatever, this is a game that will provoke some strong emotions, no matter your background. While speaking from the position of a fur-fag and being the games target audience, this game definatly hits its mark. But, by having the experience of playing through the game a few times, I can say with certainty that as long as you take the game somewhat seriously, and play it with an open mind, you'll at the very least leave with a strong connection to one or more of the characters that will leave you wanting to know more. 

As far as visual novels go, knowing nothing about this is definatly the best way to go about playing it. The diologue, while a bit rough here and there due to translation, is mostly fluid andunderstandable, but most importantly, it's impactful. One could easily become attatched to certain characters or just choose whichever character's path to follow just to see what happens. Nekojishi certainly reels you in from the beginning and doesn't let go until you're caught and served at Red Lobster with a side of butter, and to me, that's its best quality.

TL;DR

Pros:
If taken at the very least, semi-seriously, it's a fun and emotion-provoking experience

The art is very well presented, nothing is too exaggerated or over the top

The choices are a bit maze-like if trying to go for all of the endings, but most seem to be varied and different, leading to a semi-decent amount of replayability

Cons:

It's a Visual Novel so be prepared to read. A lot. If you care.

It's centered around Gay/Furry type stuff, so if that's not your thing and you don't wanna open up to it, you won't miss a whole lot.

36840769.review:
Update: Parece ser que hay una versión más completa del juego no disponible en steam por motivos esperables. Tal vez haya que probar los cambios, pero este análisis es para la versión de steam.

Reconozco que me lo he jugado por la párte gráfica de Takemoto. 
Como novela visual es bastante pobre. La continuidad de la historia es incoherente, los personajes no siguen lógica de desarrollo alguna...
Que le hayan puesto la etiqueda de"Choices matter" es una vergüenza, ya que lo que tu eligas no tiene que ver con lo que pasa prácticamente en ninguna ocasión. Hay que darle demasiadas vueltas para "complacer" a cada uno de los dioses, no porque sea difícil per se, si no porque no hay otra forma que no sea probar una y otra vez cuál es la elección correcta (cosa que no sabes hasta mucho más adelante de la elección, ya que el personaje con el que dialogues va a seguir interpretando lo que decidas como le venga en gana).
Esto por no mencionar que el protagonista es el cateto más petulante del universo. Aunque por otro lado, al estar rodeado de supuestos dioses egoístas cuyo único objetivo es abusar de él y tomar decisiones en su lugar a base de zalamerías, tampoco es que pueda llegar a mucho más. Esto también lleva a que los finales no sean particualmente positivos.
Para más inri, hay referencias que se contradicen. En ocasiones se afirman cosas que minutos antes eran de otra manera (intento no hacer spoilers).

Como detalle positivo, me gusta la idea del glosario. Al haber tanta terminología de la cultura en la que está basada el juego, poder consultar de vez en cuando qué significa cada cosa y aprender acerca de esa cultura es bastante interesante. 

TLDR: Parecía que iba a ser algo agradable y bonito de jugar, pero no. Tal vez si lo pulen mucho. Pero bueno, pruébalo y juzga por ti mismo, es gratis.

36783816.review:
[H1]Antes que nada[/h1] 

Hay que decir que... este juego esta creado POR FURRIES y su público objetivo son los mismos... aunque como todo esto no significa que sea exclusivo y que nadie más tenga derecho a jugarlo. 

Pero me parece muy patético ver que las reviews negativas son un 90 y tantos % "Huh furros dislaik :v" y el otro restante "No entendí wea ps es todo muy incoherente ps.. ps... pss" 

Es incoherente si no ves todo el argumento al 100%... lógico es como leerte un libro a capítulos sueltos.

Dicho esto pasare a hablar sobre MI experiencia y lo que me parece a diversos niveles...

[h1]Pues bien, empecemos hablando de que trata el juego[/h1]

El juego es una novela visual, es decir, encarnas el rol del protagonista y sigues una historia en la cual tu puedes tomar decisiones por las cuales la historia tomara un rumbo. 

Hasta ahí todo bien, en este caso el protagonista desciende de una familia que dirige un templo desde generaciones pero decide seguir su camino marchándose a la gran ciudad y es una vez allí cuando un poder despierta en el permitiéndole ver deidades y espíritus (entre otros)... así es como descubre que con el hay un ser espiritual que lo acompaña y dice ser ni más ni menos una de las deidades que protege a su familia por generaciones. 

El tema es que este poder es único y especial el cual no se ha vuelto a dar en generaciones, dicha deidad con forma de tigre antropomórfico le pide que vuelva a casa y guie al templo de su familia... algo que el protagonista francamente no ve entre sus planes, pero aparecerán otros que también busquen su ayuda (si los otros 2 gatetes). Es entonces cuando tendrá que tomar decisiones... ayudar a alguno o no, ayudarlos a todos y renunciar a sus sueños o seguir su vida... 

[h1]Vale... pero que te pareció el juego como tal[/h1]

Dejando de lado los gustos furrescos puedo destacar que la historia está muy bien hilada... la gente se queja de escasez de finales pero yo creo que es mejor así y no enmarañarlo todo. 

Pese a su tendencia furry homosexual, no se centra tanto como podría (porque hay otras novelas que telita...) en el tema sexual sino en la interacción y la afinidad entre los personajes la cual denotara no solo en como avanza la historia sino como entre los mismos los diversos diálogos que se dan y como los personajes tendrán en cuenta las vivencias a la hora de implicarse entre ellos.

Los personajes principales (quitando el prota porque es muy estándar el pobre XD) no voy a decir que son aquí grandes descubrimientos pero consiguen llegarte a la patatilla de algún modo... quizá hay escasez de personajes secundarios... y pese a desarrollarse en un mundo humano no se ven más que 2 en todo el juego (El prota y senpai en cierto punto) pese a que se mencionen más a lo largo del mismo (pero quien quiere ver humanos teniendo tigretones no? XDD) 


La música es espectacular, tanto el opening (que tuve que traducirlo por mis cojines <3) como la que se usa in-game consigue encajar a la perfección con los sucesos en especial en momentos alegres y tristes... *Ojito spoiler* Como cuando [Spoiler] Esa sonrisa que me salió tras ver que tras dar mil y una calabazas al pobre de Senpai y decirte que se irá para no volver pero aun así va y te pide una última cita no se me olvidara, o las lagrimas cuando vuelves y ves al leopardo hecho polvo TwT[/Spoiler]


[H1]En definitiva [/H1]

Creo que los desarrolladores pueden estar contentos con lo que han creado, se nota el mimo y el trabajo que han invertido... Hacía tiempo que no me sentía tan apegado a un juego y conseguía empaparme tanto (eww... no es lo que pensáis >:1, me refiero a la historia y personajes). 

Me gustaría apoyar a los desarrolladores (Por ejemplo si sacaran un dlc con la ost del juego, cromos, etc... ) y de ese modo ayudar al juego que aunque aun sea pronto me encantaría ver si se plantearían una secuela o algo. (Ya sé que se les puede donar, ya lo hice)

Por último un consejo totalmente imparcial y tal eh... haced siempre caso a los tigres que son buena gente <3 o buscaos un seguro de vida (yaa lo entenderéis ya) xdddd

36578214.review:
Nekojishi is a great visual novel that is definitely worth playing, or reading I guess. While the appeal is niche, at least gay but into furries helps too, Nekojishi does have a good story that provides some insight into Asian culture, allowing this game to also provide a bit of a learning experience, should you choose to look into it.

As a visual novel, the actual gameplay is pretty light, limited simply to reading and making decisions to reach a happy ending. However, that's all this game needs; the main character, Liao, is the same person regardless of how you play. Your decisions throughout the story affect which passions he chooses to pursue, but we ultimately have little agency on who Liao is. There is a golden ending to aim for, and I'd honestly recommend trying to work your way to that ending without a guide, as getting there does require a combination of getting to know each of the characters pretty well and getting the right information. While said golden ending is the only one where everyone gets a happy ending, the other endings you'll be likely to see while trying to find it are also heartwarming. Multiple playthroughs are both easy and encouraged. In addition to figuring out how to get the golden ending, there are also a few tools to use that makes things easier; a fastforward button that can skip through the parts you've already read, a glossary that keeps track of terms and other such things so you can review the concepts whenever you like, and a gallery to keep track of the events you've seen and review the great artwork that accompanies this game. Said artwork is actually quite interesting. Pretty much all of the character designs seem a little different than the usual furry art, giving the characters' an attractive appearance as well as a sort of otherwordly mystique due to their slightly non standard features. That could just be the artists' own personal touches, but they fit regardless.

Overall, Nekojishi is an amazing visual novel to experience. A great cast, heartwarming story, and outstanding visual appeal all contribute to a good game worth playing.

36531658.review:
A simple, story-filled, and well-written (at least in chinese anyways...you're going to find typos, and maybe a few sentences that doesn't make perfect sense in English) visual novel that offers you choices that will twist and turn your mind and emotions scene after scene, event after event. It keeps you going with beautiful yet simple art style and well timed sound effects to immerse you into the story as it plays out. The story and setting, background information, characters/beings mentioned can all be linked realistically to be historically accurate (View their glossary for categories of terms with given definition to describe where these terms originate from). Shouldn't bore you out, although you'd have to complete a specific set of choices to reach "true" endings for each character but it all makes sense in the end (once you reach those true endings) on why those specific choices had to be made, and the story is heavily impacted with each single choice you make that will decide which ending you will get for your playthrough. Last but not least, of course this has to be mentioned: This. Game. Is. Free. No microtransactions, no ads, no bull shit, pure quality and hard work put into this product to offer its entertainment to everyone. For free. I don't know how hard I have to stress that. The whole notion with the "furry" part obviously won't tend to and suit everyone's tastes, and it's meant for those who are fine with or into this sort of thing. I'm sure we're all mature enough to accept that fact when we're going into this game of our own choice, we're doing so knowing what it includes, and can respect it for what it is.

P.S. Yes I recieved this free game for free. Judge me.

36522755.review:
[b]WARNING: THIS GAME HAS FURRY AND HOMOSEXUAL CONTENT[/b]

[b]EDIT: I NOW OWN THE 18+ VERSION[/b]


[i]I have waited for this game for years, even since it was on Nviek's youtube channel.[/i]

I was so excited the game was translated over to english for the furry community over here in America.

The game originates from Taiwan/China, mainly with a small development team of furries over there, and a famed artist I love in the community. In China being "furry" is sorta frowned upon in my knowledge, so making this game is a big leap for furries over there in hiding, so all you guys have my support.

[i]Now the real review[/i]:
This game is on par with Morenatsu in it's homosexual content, but WAY more upfront about it. Suggesting the protagonist is indeed a furry himself, but just a fantisizer like us in the real world. I do love the slapstick humor and the cuteness, and adds a lot more realism to the situations for the protagonist. Morenatsu was a rich experience, and no doubt this should be one too. 

[i]Also, stop rating this a psychological horror game, this game was painstakingly made and deserves credit where it is due.[/i]

In short now, brilliant play, Asian made so not as crappy as Major/Minor, but except sexual content, so play when you're home alone and such. No shame doing what you like in the privacy of your own room. 

The 18+ Version (not on steam normally, but can be modded in) has some really good art, but if you want more feelies then jerkies, stay with the standard edition steam gives you. 

I'm only a few minutes in, but I had to write something positive. The furry community gets too much hate, when furries engulf a HUGE portion of steam. We just need to be strong and ignore the idiotic haters and be ourselves. This game is a strong message for that.

So be enjoy your time with Nekojishi, and be yourself while you play!~

36516464.review:
[h1]This is the perfect game for heterosexuals like myself to reassert their overabundant heterosexuality.[/h1]

     It isn't often a game will challenge heterosexuals to maintain their intimate heterosexuality, and this one is definately no different from the rest. Playing through multiple playthroughs while maintaining the "No Homo" mentality is a wonderful way to pass the time as you relentlessly buy things for your cat BFs (Best Friends) on your numerous (play) dates.

The intimate lifestyle of multiple guys living under one roof and sharing numerous interests and main characters is a genre not fully explored by mainstream developers; And indeed, those that do explore this genre tend to push the recent trend of diversity by making the main character of games engage with numerous individuals of numerous backgrounds, such as:

[list]
[*]White
[*]Black
[*]Asian
[*]Indian (India, not Native American I'm not a bigot ok)
[/list]

As you might expect, this leaves the characters to develop only on a rudimentary level without much thoughtfulness put into their character besides sweeping generalizations that feel almost unnatural. This game, Nekojishi, however explores beyond those boundries and focuses on an even closer inspection of asians. Specifically the:
[*]Japanese
[*]Chinese (Han)
[*]Some Mongol-Tribesman or something? I dunno.

This is important, because it leads us to learn more about the cultures of each of the main characters, rather than the sweeping generalizations mentioned prior. One of the specific things I was interested in was how the diets and food choices of all the main characters differed. The Chinese Tiger liked succulent roasted pig for his daily meals, whereas the nubile Leopard enjoyed a more refined pallete of tubed rice.

But even then, deeper levels of culture are revealed in this game; for example, the Chinese Tiger and the Japanese Yaokai are natural enemies and befittingly, the Japanese Kitten is ruthlessly rutted by the Chinese Tiger as sufferance for his many crimes throughout the series and in the nation-states history.

I give it a purrfect 10/10.

36509248.review:
If you play this game, play all endings!! It's like Nier in the sense that you don't see the true ending until you do every route. 

I actually cried 100 times, I played the 18+ version, which is currently free for a limited time, you can find it on their twitter or here , just look up Nekojishi 18+ english, though obviously there is some NSFW scenes in that!

This game is surpringsly well written, the dialogue is very real, every conversation feels true and not over the top like most VNs. I cried a lot, my face hurts. I also had to play through like 10 different endings (including the bad ones) to see what would happen, even the bad endings were well written though depressing obviously. Also lot's of save slots! I had to actually look up an ending guide to get all the endings then the one true ending, which I guess is a con but the true ending made it worth the hassle by far. There's a built in glossary of all the Taiwanese culture lingo used, a gallery, and below the gallery a collection of endings you've completed. Music is actually pretty impressive and some were even very powerful and emotional. If you take the time to run every ending, there is easily 20-30 hours of gameplay, which is a lot for a free VN.

The only cons I can think of is; Some messy translations throughout the game though with some imagination you can connect the dots and figure it out for yourself. Going through the story 10+ times to get every ending was a little tedious, but if you hold Ctrl down you can skip dialogue you've already read, if it stops and ctrl doesn't work, it means you are on text you haven't read yet, which was a nice indication of new text to look at, which helped greatly seeing some major and even minute differences in choices.**minor spoiler**  I wasn't a big fan of the Nier type rushed blog/computer endings, i wish they took the time to flesh those out and make them cutscenes. TOO MUCH CRYING. 

I probably put at least 30 hours into this game, 5.1 hrs on steam, and 25 hrs on the 18+ version i got on their website.

36507201.review:
So many crap lazy VNs being sold for money and one this creative and well-designed is free... what a world. [strike]Unfortunately there's no paid DLC on Steam, but you can [url=https://store.nekojishi.tw/en/product/nekojishi_limited-en/]donate on their website.[/url] (They accept PayPal; NT$ 299 ≈ $10 US.)[/strike] EDIT: [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/769180/Nekojishi_Original_Soundtrack/]There is now paid DLC on Steam.[/url]

The story starts off as gay cat harem antics, but the true end goes off in an unexpected direction. Probably disappointing if you were expecting a more traditional route structure with happy endings, but I thought it worked well. It took me about seven hours to fully complete, but it'll take a bit longer if you read slowly and/or don't use a walkthrough.

There is an R18 version with a few explicit scenes, which is a nice bonus, but I'd recommend reading the all-ages version as well, since those alternative scenes touch more on the emotional and romantic side of the relationships.

The translation isn't bad (certainly much more readable than the translation of the store page), but there's lots of small errors (mostly forgotten capitals and misplaced punctuation) which can get kind of distracting. EDIT: The translation has since been updated and corrected, but I haven't checked out the new version yet.

The art is great and the animated chibi cut-ins are just adorable. I'm not a big fan of the style where the main character sprites have a single facial expression and all of the emotions are just shown in the side images, but the art direction is dynamic and expressive enough that it still worked for me.

Even if you're not into furry art or bara, I'd recommend [i]Nekojishi[/i] to any VN fan interested in the setting. I knew nothing about Taiwanese folk religion before, and I appreciated having the in-game glossary so I could learn some interesting new facts. Plus if anyone asks, you can say you're just playing an educational game =P
