36499590.review:
***Note, I do want to keep the review as spoiler-free as possible, so do read this at your own risk.. at least hopefully that I don't screw up***

****Also, unless you're not an achievement hunter, do keep in mind that you can't be able to unlock achievements, if you imported your save file from the non-Steam version, to Steam, so ye****

*****Another note, it's best to play the game as blind as possible, and to play the clean version first, before the 18+ version... unless you're a sneaky rebel*****

Ahh yes! I've been waiting for this game to be released for 1 full year! And now that it's officially now released on Steam, I'm able to play it! Well, except a bit before, I played the 18+ version for a bit, so... ye. But yeah, it's officially on Steam now! I was genuinely afraid that it got lost in the depths of Greenlight, overlooked, but it still stands <3

But anyways, enough rambling; let's go review it... at least from the experience of playing the game in the non-Steam 18+ download, and the demo.

I know that after playing the demo before, it was pretty bare-bones as heck. There was sound, but it lacked background music, and the character portraits, mostly never change, aside from the botton corner, beside the dialog bar, for the characters other than the character you play as; Lin Tian-Liao. But now, in the official release, a TON of things were added into the game, such as the character portraits sometimes moving, having a few different portraits for each character, so you're not looking at the same portrait of the character for the entire game, more emotes for the character mugshots, the camera zooming in and moving, to make it feel a bit more engaging and fun to watch, especially when paired with certain sound effects. Heck, background music is now given this time. Though, to be fair, the demo mostly demonstrated the dialog of the game, and the translations of the game, so I couldn't complain too much on the demo.

Now, on the game's story, and its general gameplay; you play as Lin Tian-Liao, a college student who can suddenly see three "furry-beast men" spirits/gods; a tiger, a leopard, and a leopard cat. The story, well, Liao sees the three cats, they ask him things, and want to do something for Liao, depending on the spirit/god you go for. Each of the tigers you will choose to help, or go and hang out with, will increase your bond with them. Well, at least being a romance visual novel, that's how it'll usually go, right? But yeah, each of the three cats do have their own distinct personality and appearance, along with their reasons with what they want you for, and are cute in their own way.(At least not them typical anime girls you see in almost every visual novels nowadays this time, haha) :3

Being an artist myself, I do love myself some nice artstyles in games, and Nekojishi is mainly no exception. The anime style of visual novels isn't anything new, but being of anime furries, or Kemono as they call it, is kind of an interesting sight to see, instead of the usual anime. Not to diss on them anime styles, I love myself some anime(because I'm a fucking weeb), but the Kemono style is more fresher to see than the usual nowadays, since kemono games, or Kemono in general, are comparatively rare.

The most interesting part of the game, is that it gives a description of some things that are said in the game, mostly about the history, description, and other interesting trivia about Taiwanese and Chinese culture. Kind of a nice touch for the game, especially to learn more about the above cultures, that are even lesser-known. Now while I did say it's the most interesting part of the game, there's not a lot to say about it, unfortunately. Nothing new, much like the Kemono style, but it's a very interesting thing to have to just learn about the Chinese/Taiwanese cultures.

Despite many ups of the game, the game isn't exactly really that complex in its way of its relationship/bonding with the cats, especially compared to Doki Doki Literature Club. However, it's not really something to overlook, being generally cute of a game to play, and still that you can feel some bits of change for the cats, on the choices you make. Again, nothing complex, but still simple enough to understand the game, but has some moments where it's still interesting, cute and likeable.

The translation of the game, isn't really so perfect, but is still readable to understand what is being said. It's very obvious in the English translation(the game can allow you to change the language ingame, so yee), with a few spelling errors here and there. Once again, not really a problem, since there won't be any words that have too much errors to be unreadable. 

Overall, while I haven't played many kinds of visual novels nowadays, I find this visual novel game to be very interesting of its genre, and also a great visual novel game to play; it's cute, funny, and enjoyable! Just do be prepared for them adorable beast men... especially if you do try to play the 18+ version~ (which can be downloaded from their offical website. Don't worry too much if the 18+ version brings you to the store page of the game, the 18+ version is still free, don't worry; since the payment is meant as a form of donation, if you enjoyed the 18+ version :>)

***Also, had to post a short review, just for it to process much faster, and then I edited my longer detailed review in***

I do also feel that the game would make for an anime, too, I suppose as a kind of slice-of-life anime :>

Great little story about someone being awakened to see spirits, who just happen to be 3 felines (tiger, clouded leopard and leopard cat) who each want you to help them out. What do you decide? Very cutely written, a proper translation (not that common for Chinese titles) with only the minor error here and there they hopefully fix up, and quite the lenght. And that for free, so there's no reason not to give it a read... even though I'm not very fond of the ending, but there should be several so hopefully the others are more "what just happened, I have the main menu, so that was it... whaaaat?"

+Visually great. While the big portraits only have 2 stances, they do have many emotions in the little icon next to the text, and the CGI's are amazing. Only unlocked 4 of a lot more this run, so you know there's plenty to come back for.
+Story was pretty good up until the end, but maybe that's just the plot I've chosen.
+Many choices to make. So expect that 5 hours from run #1 to extend to quite a few more with re-runs.
+Relaxing music that never bothers and helps set the mood or give an upbeat while playing.
+Absolutely totally free!

-While I like the music, same can't be said for the SFX effects. While most make sense (telephone ringing, knocking on door etc.) there's some really annoying ones like the "ding" or thunder each line when they fight which are grating.
-No real way to set auto-speed that I found, and if you missed something the text will continue going reading the log. You need to remember stopping auto-play, then read the log, then auto-play again which isn't too friendly.
-The ending as mentioned, though that can just be the choices I made.
-A few typo's or grammer errors here and there. Nothing too noticable.

I went in with probably next to zero expectations outside of what I've read in the supplimentary materials to give me general characterizations of the characters, and I hadn't bothered to try out the demos, and I was pleasantly surprised by the plot.

As of writing this however, the steam achievements for it seem to be a little bricked if you import your saves from the non-steam release, so do be warned about that.
